name: Sarah Wheeler
position: Speaker | Psychologist | Writer | Consultant
about: I have worked in education and neurodiversity for almost 20 years, and my passion is to support businesses and organizations, parents, and other educators in understanding neurodivergence (ADHD, dyslexia, Autism) in children and adults and learning how to create environments that better support all kinds of minds. I write for multiple publications, and for my own newsletter, on neurodiversity, parenting, and my experience with my own ADHD. I guide parents in navigating supports and choices around their neurodivergent children. I blend expertise and lived experience with curiosity and humor.

positions.subtitle: Wheeler Psychology | Sarah Wheeler, PhD
positions.description: Design and facilitate workshops on neurodiversity, ADHD, parenting, child development, special education and related topics for organizations, institutions, and parent/community groups. Past clients include UC Berkeley Haas School of Business, MIT Media Lab, and more.

name: Samuel Ortega
position: UC Berkeley Graduate in Applied Mathematics
about:
I am a first-generation UC Berkeley Applied Mathematics graduate with a passion for actuarial science, data analysis, and financial analysis. My technical skills include proficiency in Excel, which I‚Äôve applied in various projects and roles to deliver meaningful insights and solutions. I also have experience with programming languages such as Python and SQL.

Growing up in South Central Los Angeles, I developed a deep commitment to creating a positive impact in my community. My professional journey is driven by a desire to enhance Latino representation in the actuarial and finance industries. I aim to leverage my analytical skills to contribute to a dynamic team environment, fostering innovation and continuous improvement.

Beyond my professional aspirations, I am dedicated to giving back to the community that shaped me. I hope to work with students from similar backgrounds, collaborating with school districts and administration to create opportunities and support systems that promote educational success in Los Angeles schools.

I am seeking opportunities that will allow me to grow both personally and professionally while making a tangible difference in the communities I serve.

experience.title: LSRC Finance Coordinator/Analyst
experience.description: As the Finance Coordinator/Analyst at the Chicanx Latinx Student Development Office of UC Berkeley, I played a key role in managing the financial operations to better serve Latinx students on campus. Collaborating closely with Pro Staff at the Latinx Student Resource Center, I was responsible for budgeting and processing reimbursement forms through the school administration.My role involved meticulous financial and strategic planning to ensure that resources were maximized and efficiently allocated. I focused on timely submission of forms to guarantee that students received the support they needed promptly. My efforts were instrumental in enhancing the availability of resources and support for the Latinx student community, contributing to their academic and personal success.

experience.title: Teaching Fellow
experience.description: I was a part of the IGNITE Fellowship via TFA. Here, I led a small, personalized group of second-grade students in a virtual setting. As a result, I built meaningful relationships with them and helped accelerate their academic success. In addition, I worked closely with teachers to better understand the student's curriculum and learn skills used to get them engaged in what they are learning. I took this role because our education system has unequal access to opportunity, which was seen long before the COVID-19 pandemic, especially with kids from low-income communities and communities of color. I grew up in similar circumstances as many of them, so I understand many of their struggles. I want to make a difference by being a resource for them and this opportunity let me do just that.

recommendations: Jaclyn Fidler ‚ÄúI met Jason through Scott Leese's Patreon group. He was a guest speaker and I was, well, skeptical. Having been in sales all my life, I wasn't accustomed to focusing on my breath. I was focused on caffeine, multi-tasking, and a fast-paced lifestyle. My first call with Jason was met with apprehension and resistance, my second call was met with gratitude and clarity. He was patient with me, followed up with me, and above all - opened up my mind. Jason is a wealth of knowledge and speaks from experience and from his heart. I'm so thankful he stuck with me at times when I was set in my ways. If you're in search of personal development, especially as you navigate through life in this VUCA world, call him. In return, you‚Äôll learn how to respond rather than react.‚Äù

Todd Corbin ‚ÄúJason is a gifted mindfulness facilitator and basketball coach, part of the reason being that he is incredibly thoughtful, grounded, and insightful. Jason also has amazing ability to quickly integrate new things he learns into his life and coaching. I got to know Jason from taking my 7-week Mindfulness for Student Athletes online course for sports coaches, educators, parents, and professionals. Jason coaches AAU basketball and junior college teams. It quickly became clear to myself and the class just how much wisdom Jason has gathered while coaching. When he spoke everyone listened intently. His words are carefully chosen and powerful. I asked Jason if he'd share his unique insights with the rest of the participants during one of the weekly class sessions. He prepared a 30 minute segment on the intersection between competition and mindfulness using the Michael Jordan documentary as a focal point. Jason started everyone off with a mindfulness practice that allowed all of us to reflect on some deep and thoughtful questions. All of the dozen plus participants loved the topic but more so, his wisdom and ability to make the content really come alive. I would not hesitate to ask Jason again to lead another segment for a future my class. Everyone comes away richer from his insight. ‚Äù

organizations.title: Futures Without Violence
organizations.description: Futures' Campus Leaders Fellowship program is for graduate level students with a passion for health and social justice issues. This program is unique because it gives students opportunities to change university policies, enhance curriculum, and help shift campus culture surrounding dating violence, domestic violence and sexual assault. Through the support of Futures', Jason was able to train the entire USF athletic community (student athletes, coaches, & Staff) in sexual assault awareness, healthy relationships, teamwork, responsible drinking, empathy and mindfulness. Jason is a member of the Exhibit Design Committee and has attended many conferences with Futures' as a participant and panelist. Attended spring meeting in Washington DC with cohort for White House meetings with the advisor to VP Joe Biden, Carrie Bettinger-Lopez, Department of Civil Rights, and Department of Education. Awarded USF Gender Justice Award in 2015-2016. Served as a global consultant and research lead in the fellowship program participating from abroad; in Spain and Taiwan during the 2016-2017 school year.

organizations.title: CAL Black Alumni Chapter
organizations.description: Being on the CAL Black alumni board represents healthy relationships. A healthy way of living and interacting with a group of people and/ or community. In this case the community is the African American community of UC Berkeley. Jason serves on the board to create healthy relationships between the University and the surrounding community including its prospective, current and alumni students. Building partnerships within and around the community will increase solidarity amongst the Black community as a whole in the East bay and throughout the world as Black alumni from the greatest public University in the world. Jason is a change agent, and addict for progress in our community as African Americans in higher education, but with the humility enough to include all community members who feel comfort and solace in the African American community around the University of California at Berkeley. The power of the group. It takes a village. It is extremely important to be in group. This grouping and working together does not occur in the Black community. ‚Üí Mainstream club for Networking. African American Mentoring. Share experiences as AA in the workplace.

name: Dino Ambrosi
position: Founder of Project Reboot | Helping students build healthy tech habits
about:
I help teens build healthier relationships with their devices. 

After developing and overcoming an addiction to my phone, I created a semester-long course about adopting better tech habits, which I taught at UC Berkeley. Across the 110 students who took the class, the average screen time reduction was 3.5 hours per day.

Project Reboot is my effort to bring that course to a broader audience. Through speaking, consulting, and facilitating guided digital detox programs in schools, I have helped over 5,000 teens build better tech habits.

Please shoot me a message if you are interested in bringing Project Reboot to your community or working with me directly!

experience.title: Founder
experience.description: Project Reboot is a guided digital detox program designed to help teens reset their tech habits. The program started as a semester-length course at UC Berkeley, where it helped 110 students reduce their screen time by an average of 3.5 hours per day. Today, Project Reboot is primarily run in middle & high schools via an assembly and a one-week digital detox challenge with in-class activities.
experience.description_html:
Project Reboot is a guided digital detox program designed to help teens reset their tech habits.

The program started as a semester-length course at UC Berkeley, where it helped 110 students reduce their screen time by an average of 3.5 hours per day.

experience.title: Creative Lead and Digital Strategist
experience.description: As the team leader of a group of 10 digital graphic designers and creative strategists, I was responsible for generating media content and messaging to increase campaign engagement and educate voters about the policy priorities of the "Future Generations PAC" and providing creative direction to my team. I successfully garnered over 325,000 impressions across various social media platforms using innovative marketing strategies that resonated with Gen Z audiences. You also established partnerships with over 10 prominent political advocacy media accounts to scale the campaign's storytelling efforts and align media messaging with Gen Z discourse. Additionally, I was responsible for managing the team's program budget, setting weekly agendas, and devising appropriate digital and social engagement benchmarks to ensure that media content delivery was aligned with the broader campaign schedule.

experience.title: Intern | Deputy Campaign Manager
experience.description: Interned with the political campaign of Assemblyman Kevin Kiley, who ran to become the US Representative from California's 3rd congressional district. Canvassed for votes in swing precincts, engaged in phone banking to connect with the electorate, and researched demographic trends in tossup races. Worked alongside a team of approximately 15-20 fellow interns, acquiring interpersonal skills and managerial experience. Ultimately, Assemblyman Kiley won the election over his opponent by a wide margin. In recognition of my efforts, Assemblyman Kiley proclaimed me as his deputy campaign manager.

experience.description_html:
Recruitment Process Duties
Attend, participate in, and present at all recruitment events, including Informational Sessions, Social Mixers, Coffee Chats, Interviews, and Deliberations.
Participate in recruitment tabling.
Collaborate with Project Managers to organize regular check-ins with the project’s point of contact (POC).
If needed, work with the executive team to find backup companies.

Semester Duties
Participate in committees as needed.
Act as the main executive liaison for all project managers.
Collaborate with the President and Marketing team to maintain connections with other Berkeley consulting clubs for potential partnerships.
Step in as a project manager or work with Presidents to address any vacancies in the role.
Conduct monthly check-ins with Presidents and bi-weekly check-ins with project manager pairs.
Attend project deliverables or meetings as needed, or when available, to gain insight.
Take on additional tasks to ensure smooth club operations.
Support the VP of Development in leading project management workshops as required.
Ensure project managers use provided resources like templates, trackers, slides, and agendas (created by VP Development).
Work with the President and VP of Operations to arrange and execute at least two company tours for the club.

name: Angelique Zoile
position: Management & Technology Consultant @ Forvis Mazars | UC Berkeley Haas
about:
Hey! I'm Angelique, a UC Berkeley Haas School of Business graduate with experience spanning management consulting, product development, growth marketing, and strategy & operations, with a strong emphasis on cross-functional collaboration to solve complex business problems.

üåç Growing up in France and moving to California has given me a global perspective and the ability to thrive in diverse, dynamic environments. Whether it's leading teams to execute marketing strategies, improving user experiences through data analysis, or collaborating across departments to enhance product features, I‚Äôm always eager to tackle new challenges.

üìä With experiences in various industries, I love diving deep into projects that require analytical thinking and creative solutions. My goal is to bridge the gap between business strategy and technology, and I‚Äôm constantly seeking opportunities to make an impact.

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Outside of work, I'm an adventurer at heart. From snowboarding and climbing to setting my sights on archery and golfing, I‚Äôm always exploring new activities that keep me motivated and curious.

For any inquiries, please reach out to me through e-mail: angeliquezoile@gmail.com. I'd be happy to continue chatting about our common interests, professional goals, or whatever else may be on your mind.

name: Kempton McCarty
position: USD MSBA '25 | Data-Driven Analyst | UC Berkeley Alum
about:
Passionate about transforming complex data into actionable business insights, I have advanced proficiency in Python, SQL, R, and machine learning algorithms. I'm currently advancing my analytics expertise with an M.S. in Business Analytics at the University of San Diego's Knauss School of Business, building on my strong academic background from UC Berkeley, where I earned a B.A. in Cognitive Science with a Minor in Data Science.

As a data leader at Incline Gaming Marketing, I spearheaded the creation of KPI dashboards for digital marketing campaigns that significantly reduced acquisition costs and boosted conversions. My diverse industry experience, including real-money gaming, consulting, and fashion marketing, has shaped my skills in data visualization and insight-driven analysis.

Outside of work, I am passionate about fitness, staying active through Pilates and yoga. I'm eager to contribute my analytical skills to innovative technology teams in the San Francisco Bay Area as a data scientist/analyst following my graduation in May 2025. Let's connect!

experience.title: Developer
experience.description: I led a team of UC Berkeley students to create machine learning algorithms that identify types of misinformation ahead of elections in both the US and the EU in June and November. We developed a variety of data visualizations to identify the most common types of misinformation that consumers encounter. We analyzed trends across six types of misinformation, finding sourcing and language errors to make up 70% of misinformation. This finding helped us determine the types of misinformation people should be aware of to be more intelligent media consumers.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: I collaborated with a cross-functional team of UC Berkeley students who participated in the fall 2023 Datathon hosted by the United Nations. Our objective in this Datathon was to tie our work from the non-profit Educ8 to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. We focused our research on food insecurity by implementing XGBoost and Random Forests, resulting in more than 80% accuracy in predicting a nation's food insecurity levels. We analyzed data to provide insights on key factors that inform policy-driven economic strategies on what countries around the world should focus on to reduce food insecurity.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: I partnered with a team of UC Berkeley data science students and worked together to create a curriculum that exposes high school students to the field of data science in countries worldwide. Along with my team, I accomplished this by applying consumer behavior analytics to develop and manage educational content. Once we developed this curriculum, it educated hundreds of high school students, resulting in a 100% improvement in their data literacy rates. This exposure gave these students a greater understanding of all the fields in which data science can be applied.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: A team of 5 UC Berkeley students and I worked with a corporate mentor outside the standard curriculum. We executed a research project to develop a greater understanding of how technology intersects with National Security. In this project, my peers and I researched how deep-fakes, misinformation/disinformation, phishing/spear-phishing, and echo chambers can potentially create significant National Security risks for the US Military. We presented how deep-fakes, disinformation, and cybersecurity threats across 3 case studies contribute to National Security, increasing viewers' awareness by 75%, and providing strategic insights into audience perception with commonly used digital content.
positions.title: Researcher
positions.description_html: A team of 5 UC Berkeley students and I worked with a corporate mentor outside the standard curriculum. In this project, my peers and I researched how deep-fakes, misinformation/disinformation, phishing/spear-phishing, and echo chambers can potentially create significant National Security risks for the US Military. We presented how deep-fakes, disinformation, and cybersecurity threats across 3 case studies contribute to National Security, increasing viewers' awareness by 75%, and providing strategic insights into audience perception with commonly used digital content.

experience.title: Researcher
experience.description: I designed and executed a data science-driven research project in place of internships, which were all canceled due to COVID, and studied the relationship between the strictness of lockdown and the number of COVID cases. Using data from the Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center and Financial Times, I created a regression analysis that compared the rate of increase in COVID cases to the strictness of the lockdown at given points in time. This statistical comparison aimed to see how effective lockdowns were in mitigating COVID cases at given points in time. I evaluated six countries, one from each of the six continents, finding that countries that implemented lockdown restrictions earlier in the pandemic had 50% lower cases of COVID compared to countries that did not lockdown earlier. In other words, my analysis showed that the timing of when a lockdown was imposed dramatically affects how well cases are mitigated versus the strictness of the lockdown. I developed a new understanding of how statistics can be used in epidemiology, as well as the amount of power governments have when handling and mitigating the effects of any crisis imposed on their citizens.

name: Sungha C.
position: Rhetoric @ UC Berkeley
about:
As a Rhetoric major at UC Berkeley with an anticipated graduation in May 2025, I've honed my skills in relationship building and team leadership. My recent role as a Project Consultant at IDEA Factory Consulting entailed developing outreach strategies and a successful conversion rate. In parallel, my position as Social Chair strengthened my event planning and financial oversight capabilities, ensuring memorable experiences for over 30 members.

Our team's efforts in competitive analysis and marketing strategies yielded insightful entry points into the Gen-Z market for our clients. We fostered a culture of engagement and innovation, where I learned that active participation drives community involvement. Looking ahead, I am eager to leverage these experiences to contribute to an organization's growth, aligning with its values and enriching its culture with diverse perspectives.

name: Eric Van Dusen
position: Technology and Outreach Lead -  Data Science Undergraduate Studies, UC Berkeley
about:
I am currently working on curriculum development for Data Science Education at UC Berkeley, working on getting an open source common data analysis framework into a  wide range of classes and departments.  We work with instructors from across campus to develop open-source interactive curriculum that is deployed on a cloud-based campus server.  Two of our flagship programs are Data Science Connectors, two-unit domain seminars to accompany the Data-8 class, and Data Science Modules, that introduce Data Science into existing courses.  I also facilitate summer workshops teaching our faculty, and instructors from across the country,  to use data science pedagogy in their classes . 

In Fall 2017, I developed a class teaching international development through the tools of the Data 8 Intro to Data Science course at Berkeley, and I got hooked!  In Spring 2019 I taught an undergraduate Data Science Connector course on Reproducibility and Open Science, and went on to work with a student team in developing another one on Economic Modeling for Fall 2019, that is still being taught.   
 
I have worked the areas of applied economics analysis of international and environmental issues in a variety of system and settings. I have always had an interest in how socially focussed research can benefit society and have worked on a variety of issues of political importance but in a micro- applied research setting. I am now working on the vision on how to get students to learn through hands-on experiences in reproducibility, interactive computing, and research exposure.

experience.title: PREP Instructor/Design Assistant
experience.description: UC Berkeley's Pre-Engineering Program hosts a series of classes that introduces incoming freshmen to STEM courses offered in the college of engineering. As a design assistant, I was responsible for scripting lectures and teaching incoming EECS students how to code in Python. I also worked as a teacher's assistant for the design studio course that teaches over 100 students electrical engineering and entrepreneurship.

experience.title: Instructor
experience.description: Bluestamp is a teaching startup that offers its students many opportunities to learn electrical, mechanical, and software engineering in one fell swoop based on their chosen project. They are given 3-6 weeks to create something from the Bluestamp project book, then present their work at the end of the program, building upon their public speaking skills. As an instructor, I was responsible for helping students complete their projects, allowing me to learn electrical, mechanical, and software engineering while acting as a project advisor for students building a custom Amazon Alexa, a smart mirror, and neural net for hummingbird detection.

experience.title: Summer Intern
experience.description: The Watershed Project is a non-profit organization based in Richmond, California. Their goal is to clean out rivers and creeks that carry pollutants into the Bay. We also logged the garbage found in the watersheds and use it to create informational flyers to discourage littering of those specific items. I wrote articles for the company website, organized information meetings, and documentary screenings, and created infographics for the company's social media sites.

projects.title: The Pulse Mixer
projects.description: Info 262, Tangible Interfaces, is a graduate course where students learn important design, software, and electrical engineering principles to create a final project by the end of the semester. My project group created the pulse mixer, initially designed to be a museum exhibit where attendees interact with a circular mat to engage in sound engineering. Our final product was a scaled-down version of the exhibit, maintaining the same themes and functionality.

projects.title: Evaluating the Robustness of Neural Networks
projects.description: EECS 127, Optimization Models in Engineering, provides students the opportunity to conduct a literature review through mathematical practice. Our project reviews Carlini and Wagner's paper "Towards Evaluating the Robustness of Neural Network" and explores other applications of adversarial machine learning samples. We made this examination in the realm of digital online art.

organizations.title: Berkeley Center for New Media
organizations.description: The Bottomlands BCNM project aims to locate graves in the Lower Mississippi River Basin that are unmarked or poorly recorded, most of which are Black families and formerly enslaved people. The project aims to address the erasure of these sites as ongoing construction projects continue.In this role, I am responsible for transcribing data, manually locating gravesites, organizing data into digital repositories, verifying this information, and organizing this data into digital databases for future research projects and families who wish to locate the burial sites of their ancestors.

organizations.title: BESSA
organizations.description: As president, I am responsible for managing a board of 19 people who host corporate and social events and programming for pre-collegiate students. I oversee our weekly tutoring and career readiness programs. I maintain strong relationships with neighboring NSBE chapters and other Black/engineering organizations on Cal's campus by hosting joint events and promoting camaraderie. I assist with fundraising for our organization and host faculty dinners and general body meetings.This year, I had the honor of relaunching our annual career fair and launching a "Good Study Habits and Time Management" course for underrepresented undergraduates to help them raise their GPAs. I am responsible for maintaining our previous programming and introducing new services to the Black student body. I oversee and participate in all of the services we provide.

organizations.title: Girls Who Code
organizations.description: Girls Who Code is an affinity group for women in software engineering and development. As technical program lead, I create lectures and workshops for members to improve their technical and soft skills in programming, focusing on communication, confidence, and execution.

organizations.title: PLAIT Lab
organizations.description: The PLAIT Lab aims to develop low-code and no-code interfaces for data work, powered by next-generation predictive programming techniques. Within the PLAIT Lab, I work with Professor Sarah Chasins investigating how newer programmers interact with unfamiliar abstractions in computer science. I conducted 90-minute user studies to gather data for the project. Upon completion, I helped co-author a paper on our findings which was submitted to the Computer-Human Interaction (CHI) Conference this fall.

organizations.title: NSBE
organizations.description: The National Society of Black Engineers aims to increase the number of culturally responsible Black Engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community. My role as PCI Chair is to engage with younger students who aren't in college yet, and encourage them to pursue a degree in engineering.I was responsible for hosting an annual conference where they can build upon their technical and soft skills. This year I held a cultural responsibility workshop, two coding workshops, three design workshops, two math competitions, and took them on a college tour of Santa Clara University for 40 students and chaperones.

organizations.title: BESSA
organizations.description: UC Berkeley's NSBE chapter, more formally known as BESSA, is an organization that recruits Black and mixed heritage students pursuing degrees in STEM. The club offers exclusive internship and job opportunities, access to NSBE conferences, and academic support throughout the school year. As external vice president, I am responsible for organizing and hosting corporate events, office tours, fundraising, and maintaining strong relationships with our neighboring NSBE chapters.

organizations.title: DataGood
organizations.description: DataGood is a data science consulting company run by Berkeley students that teaches its members how to code in Python and use various data science Python libraries to analyze data. As a project manager, I was responsible for writing a learning curriculum that upper and lowerclassmen how to code and analyze data. I wrote their capstone project where they analyzed global vaccine distribution data to determine whether or not vaccines were being distributed equitably.

organizations.title: Pioneers in Engineering
organizations.description: Pioneers in Engineering is a robotics program run by UC Berkeley students. They work with high schools around the Bay Area to prepare them for bi-annual competitions where we build a robot to complete that season's game. As club president, I was responsible for organizing transport for a team of ~20 students, writing code to control the robot remotely, delegating tasks during competitions, and teaching students how to code in Arduino per their request.

name: Pamela Gleason
position: Author of Berkeley Guidebook, MaCSS Student Services Director, History Buff, Airbnb Tour Leader, Founder of the Hillside Fire Safety Group, Founder of PATHS LLC Adventures, Around-the-World Backpacker, Weekend Gardener
about:
I‚Äôm honored to work at UC Berkeley, which I'm convinced is the best university in the world.  Recently I joined several of my favorite faculty members to launch a new program called the Master of Computational Social Science, which teaches students to use data science tools for social good. 
 
In my career at UC Berkeley I've learned from researchers, educators, journalists, a business leaders. I'm lucky to be working with the best data scientists and machine learning experts in the world.  My colleagues and students have given me a front seat to the most recent developments and reveal compelling stories of innovation and perseverance.  

I enjoy connecting people.  I enjoy watching ideas and dreams come true ‚Äî and after traveling to 60+ countries, I'm pretty sure Berkeley is the best place on the planet for this!  

I'm an international traveler, published author, and local history buff.  My heroes are the people who make us pause, think, and set out to be better.  My book, Berkeley Guidebook: Adventures at the Vortex of Ideas and Audacity, is available online and at bookstores.  It's about the history and unsung heroes of Berkeley's past (with a few villains too!) based on the original research I did for my walking tours.  If you'd like a tour, you can book me through Airbnb.

positions.description: Berkeley is known for high quality education, entrepreneurial spirit, and an exceptional faculty.  Our two year Master of Journalism program is for talented up-and-coming journalists who are dedicated to the craft of reporting.  Our students specialize in hard-core investigative research, visual storytelling, long form feature writing, and using the latest media tools to produce high quality news content. As Director of Career Services, I connect our students to the best internships and jobs using our strong network of successful alumni and industry leaders.  Investigative journalism is key to making the world a better place.  I'm super lucky to be a part of this dedicated community.

publications.title: TGL-Lambda: An implementation of TrapGrid to estimate trap attractiveness from heterogeneous field data
publications.subtitle: Arxiv
publications.description: This paper describes a recently developed software called ``TGL-Lambda'' enables quantifying lure attractiveness under a variety of field capture scenarios including mixed lure/trap combinations. TGL-Lambda delivers a flexible approach to simultaneously estimating the "lambda" value for multiple trap types, accommodating a common situation in ``Mark-release-recapture'' (MRR) experiments in the field. Specifically, where researchers release a known number of marked insects in a field and count how many are recaptured in two to five trap and lure types, and the trap and release locations are known, TGL-Lambda can be used to estimate the attractiveness (lambda) of each of the trap types.

projects.title: TGL Lambda
projects.description: While working at the USDA, I noticed that we could use an easier way to calculate the attractiveness level of a lure, which we call 1/Œª (the distance in which the probability of the lure succeeding is 65%). I also saw that a huge problem we faced is that when we were given experiments that involved multiple types of lures, there are far too many different possible combinations of attractiveness for the lures.To solve these problems, I created an updated version of our java software known as "TrapGrid". My program, called "TGL Lambda" is in Python and it essentially allows the user to input their experiment, including the number of traps and different lures used, the locations of these traps, and their recorded recapture rate, and it calculates the possible levels of trap attractiveness for each of the lures used. It uses Latin Hypercube Sampling to find a smaller number of combinations that should still display the area of the specific ones which we believe, after complex mathematical equations and calculations, could have led to the user's recapture rate. TGL Lambda is now available on GitHub, and its research paper is available on arXiv.https://github.com/benscalero/TG-Laboratory/tree/main/TGL-Lambdahttps://arxiv.org/abs/2408.05408

name: Olivia M.
position: Monetization DS @ Pinterest üìå
about:
As a Machine Translation Researcher at Data Science Discovery Program, I train, deploy, and evaluate neural networks that translate Cuneiform scripts to modern languages. I strive to use my background in the philosophy of science and technology to foreground human-centered design principles during NLP innovation. 

I am currently a Data Science Master's candidate at UC Berkeley's School of Information, and graduated this past May from UC Berkeley with General Distinction in my studies in Data Science and Rhetoric. Additionally, I received departmental recognition in Rhetoric for my Honors Thesis research on Statistical Language Modeling. 

 My academic background combines technical skills in data analysis, machine learning, and data engineering, with rhetorical skills in public speaking, leadership, and written communication. I am passionate about bringing data-driven solutions to industry problems, and leveraging my rhetorical expertise to effectively and efficiently mobilize teams in engineering settings.

name: Daisy Khamphakdy
position: Data Scientist | Data Analytics | Master of Information and Data Science graduate from UC Berkeley School of Information
about:
As a dedicated Data Scientist with extensive experience as a Data Analyst, my passion lies in leveraging data analytics and machine learning to generate value for businesses and society. My unconventional journey integrating analytics to high-stakes social impact work, alongside my refugee background, profoundly shapes my approach to data science. This influence instills a results-driven, holistic, agile, and intentional design to analytics and algorithms that drive meaningful outcomes. I‚Äôm eager to be applying my unique skills in the tech space.

--
Programming Languages: SQL, Python, R, HTML
Operating Systems: Ubuntu, MacOS, Windows
Database/Server: SQL (MySQL, Postgres), NoSQL (MongoDB, Neo4j, Redis)
Libraries/Packages: Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, Seaborn, Scikit-learn, TensorFlow, Keras, ggplot2, tidyr
Technical Tools: Tableau, PowerBI, Jupyter Notebooks, Github, Git
Cloud Computing Platforms: AWS, Google Cloud Platform
Machine Learning Algorithms: Regression models, Classification models, Tree-based models, Clustering, Deep Learning, Time-series Forecasting, LLM (large language models - BERT, GPT-3, T5, OPT, RoBERTa)
Statistics: A/B Testing, Causal Inference, Time Series Analysis, Experimentation

projects.title: [Classification] Detect Emerging Crises
projects.description: Applied NLP algorithms to create a predictive model and visualization tool to detect disaster tweets and aggregate critical information to assist relief efforts. Employed techniques such as linearSVC, logistic regression, multinomial naive bayes, random forest, and large language models (LLMs) to accomplish the task.

projects.title: [Classification] Spotify Song Genre Prediction
projects.description: Created song genre classification algorithms to automatically and accurately predict and categorize a song‚Äôs genre that would improve song library customization by learning what song genres were listened to most. Used Random Forest, XGBoost, Neural Network, and Logistic Regression and found that Random Forest had the best accuracy scores after datasets were balanced, normalized, and standardized.

projects.title: [NoSQL Databases] Strategic Store Locations using Shortest Path Algorithms
projects.description: Tasked with finding the most profitable areas to set up healthy meal stations along the BART trains stations, we identified optimal locations using NoSQL databases (including Neo4j, MongoDB, and Redis) and applied Dijkstra's algorithm. We determined five efficient train paths meeting criteria for the shortest distance.

projects.title: [Text Generation] Predict Story Ending
projects.description: Built predictive NLP models that generated story endings given unique story contexts. Used TensorFlow and PyTorch to create bidirectional LSTM, BERT, T5 and OPT models that generated fluent and coherent sentences and applied BLEURT, ROUGE, and human evaluation to evaluate the quality of the text generation outputs.

name: Katie Gede
position: Higher Education Leader & Problem Solver
about:
I am a higher education problem solver and program manager with a Master's in Education from the University of California, Davis. I have over ten years of experience working in higher education solving administrative problems for students, faculty, and staff, specifically in the University of California system. I currently work at UC Berkeley for the School of Information as the Director of Operations on the Student Affairs team. I specialize in scheduling and enrollment planning/management for the I School and currently supervise and manage the scheduling and enrollment staff on the Student Affairs team.

Previously I worked in the Office of Planning and Analysis (OPA) as an Institutional Research Analyst and in the Graduate School of Education at UC Berkeley, as a Project/Policy Analyst. I also worked in the Contracts and Grants Office at UC Davis prior to completing my graduate degree at UC Davis. My Master's thesis was a quantitative study which examined the relationship between a student's pre-collegiate determinants and their academic performance in higher education, particularly at the California State University system.

For the past 10+ years, I have worked in higher education administration, which has included graduate degree program management which includes curriculum planning (scheduling and enrollment management), Academic Student Employee policy, allocations, & hiring, student advising and working with non-traditional part-time professional graduate students, managing, recruiting, and training staff, and event project management. I've also researched issues in higher education, including undergraduate education and have Research Administration experience.

positions.subtitle: UC Berkeley School of Information

name: Aadi Shah
position: DS @ UC Berkeley
about:
As an undergraduate data science major, I am deeply passionate about using technology to make a positive impact on society. My high interest in data science has led me to pursue projects and experiences that can aid the impaired through adaptive technology, such as the Overhead Movement Alarm Radar, a prototype I and several others have developed in order to assist visually impaired individuals in preemptively detecting overhead obstacles.

In order to further my ability to work in data science, I have gained a foundational understanding of various topics, including adversarial machine learning, machine learning robustness, and AI safety. In particular, I am extremely passionate about adversarial machine learning, and am hoping to pursue research involving making classifiers more robust to adversaries. In my volunteer work, I have mentored younger students in mathematics and programming with my experience from AIME and USACO Platinum and hosted data science seminars.
 
I am eager to connect with other like-minded individuals and professionals who share my passion for data science and innovation. Feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions or suggestions, or just want to hold a conversation.

name: Asbah Wasim
position: UX Researcher | Merging Cognitive Science, Data Science & Design to Develop User-Centered Experiences
about:
Hello! My name is Asbah, and I am from the Bay Area. I am studying Cognitive Science, Data Science, and Design Innovation at UC Berkeley. Through my majors and the courses I have taken, I have gained experience and connected human cognition, user data, research, and design to produce engaging, inclusive, and positive experiences. I am passionate about solving real world problems by integrating human cognition, data, and design, to ultimately create optimal experiences. 

My love for design first spurred when I took Interior Design in high school. I remember learning about the principles of design for the first time. Having taken the design that surrounded me for granted before this, my eyes opened to small details I hadn't ever noticed before. I became excited for the endless doors of opportunities that opened because of this. I competed at the Regionals FCCLA Competition in February 2020, where I applied my newly acquired skills to design my client's home. There, I won first place and advanced on to win first place at the State level.  

When I came to UC Berkeley, I hadn't completely decided what I wanted to study. After learning about human-computer interactions in my Introduction to Cognitive Science course, my interest in UX began. I value user feedback and believe that one of the most crucial components to a website, app, or product is understanding how the user interacts with it. After all, without the user, there is no product. 

My interests in research, human cognition, and design have prompted me to study Data Science, Cognitive Science, and Design Innovation at UC Berkeley. By taking courses in these fields, I have realized how perfectly they work together. Without collecting and understanding user data, it is difficult to truly understand the user and their experiences. Failing to understand the user prevents the creation of optimal design. I hope to use my skills in data science, cognitive science, and design to organize and interpret user feedback to ultimately create effective experiences.  

Living in this day and age, there are numerous problems that face us today, and there is need for significant global change. Specifically concerned about the rise in crime, the environment, and inclusive education, I am passionate about applying my skills in design, research, and data science to design innovative experiences and solutions. In doing so, I hope to do my part as a changemaker for tomorrow's future.

Feel free to connect with me and check out my website at https://asbahwasim.wixsite.com/asbah-wasim. Thank you for stopping by!

projects.title: Markov Chains Prediction for HIV Patients
projects.description: Developed a Markov chain model to analyze HIV patient treatment outcomes and predict the effectiveness of different drug regimens. The model evaluated transition probabilities between health states and identified optimal treatment protocols for achieving and maintaining viral suppression. This research was conducted as part of the Big Data Health Science Competition at USC.

projects.title: Pac-Man AI
projects.description: Developed multiple python Pac-Man projects using informed state-space search, probabilistic inference, and reinforcement learning.Implemented depth first search, breadth first search, and A* search algorithms to help Pac-Man find food while avoiding ghosts. Designed different types of Pac-Man agents based on minimax, alpha-beta, and expectimax search and Q-learning. Used probabilistic inference (variable elimination, exact inference, joint particle filtering) to design Pacman agents that use sensors to locate and eat invisible ghosts.

projects.title: Predicting Housing Prices
projects.description: Conducted exploratory data analysis to analyze inequities in housing prices in Cook County, Illinois. Predicted housing prices using a multiple linear regression model in Cook County, Illinois using Python.

projects.title: Interactive Travel Map
projects.description: Created an interactive travel map to showcase 30+ places I‚Äôve visited in a clear, enjoyable manner for my blogImplemented a pop-up description for each travel location with hyperlinks to my blog using Folium and HTMLIntegrated Geopandas and choropleth to dynamically color countries based on the number of times I visited themImplemented web scraping to extract the latitude, longitude, and description of each location that I‚Äôve traveled

projects.title: Gitlet
projects.description: Engineered local version control system in Java, using serializable objects and commandsIncorporated the standard Java library to implement functions of git (init, add, commit, merge, branch, checkout, and status)

projects.title: Multiple Linear Regression - California Waste Data
projects.description: The goal of this report is to evaluate how land use variables predict the amount of solid waste in millions of tons. The Solid Waste Data provides measurements on several land user variables affecting solid waste produced in 40 regions in a nine-county area of California. The land use variables include acres of industrial land, acres of fabricated metals, acres of trucking and wholesale trade, acres of retail trade, acres of restaurants and hotels, acres of finance / insurance / real estate, acres of miscellaneous services, and acres of residential land. The solid waste variable was calculated from economic models and is measured in millions of tons. To achieve the goal of studying how land use variables predict solid waste, this report uses the R programming language, multiple programming libraries, and statistical techniques to employ a multivariate linear regression model.

projects.title: ACID-Compliant Database Recovery Implementation
projects.description: ‚Ä¢ Implemented ACID-compliant recovery mechanisms including write-ahead logging, savepoints, and rollback capabilities to ensure database integrity and consistency during normal operations and crash recovery‚Ä¢ Engineered comprehensive restart recovery processes by implementing analysis, redo, and undo phases, allowing the database to efficiently restore a valid state post-crash‚Ä¢ Utilized functional programming techniques in Java to streamline the implementation of complex recovery tasks, such as undoing changes and managing logs, ensuring reliable database performance

experience.title: Undergraduate Researcher (Data Science Discovery Program)
experience.description: - Conducted data science research at the U.S. Air Force Operational Energy to optimize fuel logistics networks and build operational plans that address risk- We used a multiple regression model to train our data. For every flow object, the flow along each edge is an input variable and the score for the entire flow plan is the output variable. We chose to use a regression model because it works best with the data points we have (various numerical features that correspond to a numerical output).- Conducted Data Science and Machine learning research at the U.S. Air Force Operational Energy: Used a Multiple Regression Model with Exploratory Data Analysis, Neural Network, Seaborn Graphs and Tensorflow to optimize fuel logistics networks and built operational plans that address risk; Found the maximum score to a flow object in the dataset was roughly 76%

recommendations: G. Allen Ratliff ‚ÄúI am happy to recommend Shirley for a wide variety of projects and roles. Shirley is an effective team player who is diligent to ensure that they understand their individual tasks and how they fit within projects and connect to the work of their colleagues. Shirley is respectful and thoughtful, contributing positively to team culture and atmosphere. Shirley asks clear questions, offers well-considered ideas, and is an active participant in brain-storming, problem-solving, and action-planning. In addition, Shirley is able to work independently to find answers to problems that arise in their work, taking steps to explore how colleagues and peers have overcome similar problems, and working to implement strategies to eliminate process and programmatic barriers toward long-term solutions. I would be happy to work with Shirley again in the future and I am confident that Shirley would be a valuable addition to any team or project.‚Äù

projects.title: Ripple: Educational Crowdfunding App
projects.description: iOS developer and leader for Ripple, mobile platform that for women around the world to crowdfund their educational pursuits. Ripple was selected as a Global Semifinalist representing the United States in the 2017 Technovation Challenge. Utilized object oriented programming and Core Location, hosted Parse server on Heroku and AWS, implemented querying.

projects.title: Bene: Virtual Stress-Management Toolkit for High School Students
projects.description: Inspired by the rise of student suicides in our hometown, myself and two other Castilleja students decided to help our community by providing a virtual toolkit of stress-management techniques to high school students. I developed and shipped the app, Bene, which provided features such as an interactive daily health checklist, a virtual diary to store meaningful memories, and support hotline connections. I built Bene in Swift utilizing Cloud Computing, querying and retrieving information from Parse, and object-oriented principles.

projects.description: Attended a 6-week machine learning STEM module and built functioning digit-classification program. Learned about linear & logistic regression and huber functions.

name: Carina Samson
position: Research Study Coordinator/Lab Manager @UChicago | Data Science and Psychology @UC Berkeley
about:
I am passionate about using research and data analysis to understand human emotions, values, and behaviors to serve our community. To explore these ideas, I pursued dual degrees in Data Science and Psychology, graduating with Highest Honors from UC Berkeley.

I currently work as a full-time Research Study Coordinator/Lab Manager in the University of Chicago's Memory Research Lab. In our lab, we use research tools from cognitive psychology and neuroscience to explore cognitive aging and identify the mechanisms that drive memory accuracy and distortion in different contexts. My role involves programming computerized cognitive tasks using JavaScript, HTML/CSS and Python, recruiting and testing research participants, training and coordinating research assistants,  and managing IRB protocols and grant funding.

During my time at UC Berkeley, I worked as a Research Assistant in the Computational Psychiatry and Affective Cognitive Neuroscience Lab under Professor Sonia Bishop, where I conducted research on how limited sleep impacts the interplay between anxiety, depression, and decision-making. I also completed my Senior Honors Thesis under Professor Iris Mauss in the Emotion and Emotion Regulation lab, exploring ethnic variation in emotion judgments and their implications for psychological health.

projects.title: IMPACT Project
projects.description: ASIJ's IMPACT program is a personalized learning course that consists of four components: Design for IMPACT, IMPACT Seminar, IMPACT Network and a Presentation of Learning. IMPACT allows students with a desire to explore a particular passion, who are motivated by a certain problem or challenge, to become change-makers and make a difference. I've developed a project which aims to use positive psychology as a tool to improve student wellbeing, through fostering a positive school and home environment, specifically by:- Implementing positive psychology in student advisory sessions and in training sessions for my school's Student Advisory Council (SAC) members- Writing weekly articles about positive psychology for my school‚Äôs Parent Bulletin- Completing a Common Sense Media Educator badging pilot session for faculty at my school to promote and disseminate digital citizenship in the classroom.

projects.title: TEDxYouth@ASIJ: Bumps In The Road
projects.description: TEDxYouth@ASIJ is a student-driven project that sprung from the ASIJ Impact program, with the aim of self-efficacy and learning. Our event, which is licensed through the TEDx program of the TED conference, showcases ASIJ‚Äôs ideas worth spreading. Through hosting an annual TEDx conference, we aim to involve students at ASIJ on all sides of the event: whether they are organizing, speaking or attending. This event, which is in its second year, is dedicated to including all members of the ASIJ community.

name: Maria Jose Healey
position: Data Science Graduate Student at UC Berkeley School of Information
about:
One of my childhood dreams was to be a polyglot. Learning English in a very small town in the southeast of Bolivia was so much fun but not conducive to the pursuit. As I learned this new language, I familiarized myself with computers and realized I could learn multiple programming languages. An opportunity presented itself and I made one of the biggest decisions in my life - moving abroad to the States. 

Being a wife and mother is part of my identity but that is not all I wanted to be. So, I decided to go back to school and obtained a B.S. in Computer Science. One of the projects I enjoyed the most during undergrad was focused on predictive analytics, specifically how to understand customer behavior by using unsupervised machine learning algorithms.  My research was centered on customer segmentation and the K-Means algorithm. 

This experience sparked my interest in machine learning models and their role in supporting data-driven decision-making. Having gained more awareness of my interests and improved my communication, problem-solving skills, and adaptability, I decided to pursue a masters in Data Science. This role has been helping me learn to develop and expand personal aptitudes such as analytical, management, and data analytics skills.  My goal is to become a machine learning engineer.

My foremost strength is perseverance. I lived through economic hardships and limited opportunities which taught me to go the extra mile when an opportunity appears. I feel happy and productive, while at work. Time is very precious to me but it passes like a bullet-train when enjoying family, playing basketball or pickleball, walking, hiking or traveling.  I also find coding to solve a problem a thrill all on its own. If something catches my interest, motivation surges and I jump into action.

Please, feel free to contact me via LinkedIn. I would love to receive tips that could help me land my dream job in the field of machine learning. Also, I‚Äôm always looking forward to a conversation about animals, or the NBA.

name: Heather Holly-Freitag
position: Comprehensive College Planning at Options Abound Educational Consulting LLC
about: I come to the work of college planning from a strong background in clinical social work.  My graduate degree, professional experience, and practical parenting, have prepared me well to meet the needs of high school students and their families.  With years of counseling and advocacy experience, I comfortably navigate difficult conversations.  Particularly today, when many of our students are stressed and experiencing anxiety and depression, my clinical background offers a degree of expertise that de-stresses the entire college application journey.  A decade ago, in the thick of raising our four children, I helped parents troubleshoot when they found their students struggling in the typical classroom.  From assisting with college planning to homeschool curriculum advice, I partnered with families as they navigated the confusing landscape of educational options.   As my own children entered high school and I led them through college applications, I developed a love and passion for the work.   I returned to the classroom and completed the UC Irvine "Certificate in Independent Educational Consultant" coursework. Today, I am thrilled to be working as a Comprehensive College Planning IEC.   I work diligently to make the college application process smooth and joyful, removing some of the typical stresses associated with the college application journey.    In my work as an educational consultant, I readily serve as guide and facilitator and remove parent/guardian from the role of task manager.  I will walk the student through the entire process of finding a college match. Visiting and researching colleges throughout the United States enables me to work on optimal college fit.  I develop a timeline for the student, identify and coordinate testing and tutoring, assess student strengths and challenges, survey career options, discover their unique college fit, advise in college application completion, brainstorm and proofread essays, and educate on financial aid and merit aid.  I am passionate about getting students to tell their own story in a way that is engaging and powerful.   Reach out to me today to learn more about my services.

experience.title: Independent Educational Consultant
experience.description: Passionately partnering with students as they navigate their educational options. Validating the dignity, worth, and potential that each life holds, while empowering students to aim high and work hard to achieve their goals.  Enthusiastically guiding students to a college match that is full of opportunity and promise.  Comprehensive College Planning: first-generation students, highly capable learners, student athletes and student artists (musicians, animation, dance), college applications to highly selective colleges, and matching students to colleges that meet the family financial budget.  Located in the beautiful Pacific Northwest in Clark County, Washington. In-person and virtual consultation services.

name: Chelsea Jimenez
position: Master's Student in Computational Social Science @ UC Berkeley
about:
I began my career in education, working for three years as a Jumpstart AmeriCorps member in Oakland, CA, where I supported preschool-aged children in underserved communities. After the COVID-19 pandemic, I noticed a rise in language and fine motor skill delays among students and became increasingly aware of the systemic gaps in educational resources. This sparked my interest in exploring data-driven solutions beyond direct service.

This curiosity led me to research, and I joined UC Berkeley‚Äôs Language and Cognitive Development Lab, working on a COVID & Child-Directed Speech project analyzing how pandemic-related stressors affected caregiver-child interactions. Using R for linguistic analysis, I examined speech patterns and later developed my own ICBS-funded research project on how caregiver mood influenced affective language use.

I later earned a B.A. in Psychology from UC Berkeley, where I combined my interests in human behavior and data analysis. Alongside research, I worked as an Intervention Specialist at Lincoln Families, applying data-driven intervention strategies to support students with developmental and learning disabilities. Tracking student progress through data collection and analysis reinforced my belief in the power of data to drive informed decision-making in education and social policy.

Now, as a COOP fellow and a Master‚Äôs student in Computational Social Science at UC Berkeley, I am refining my skills in Python, R, SQL, causal inference, and machine learning to analyze complex social issues. With a background in education, psychology, and research, I aim to leverage data science techniques to inform policy, improve educational interventions, and drive meaningful societal change.

          The Department of Electronics & Instrumentation Engineering (EIE) has a society, the INSEES (Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering Society), comprising of the faculty and student members of the department. The society has been formed with a view to promote various technical activities among the students. It aims to play an active role in the development of students as potential engineers by various out-of-curriculum and extra-curricular activities including organizing of seminars, paper presentations, debate, quiz and software contests. The society also organises socialisation programmes for the freshmen in the society.

name: Tilda Gross, MSOD
position: Principal Consultant - Career and Talent Development
about:
Hi--I'm Tilda! 
My career thus far has been defined by helping safe and inclusive spaces flourish in the corporate world. I am a career coach, community builder, program manager, and organization development practitioner. Working in edtech, academia, and consulting the past few years, the things that get me excited to wake up in the morning are:

- Making data visualizations in order to make data-driven decisions (data viz nerd!) The data I love most usually involves looking at retention rates, satisfaction, happiness, or tracks back to diversity, inclusion or belonging. The best data insights come from using a mixture of qualitative and quantitative data
- Propelling a positive employee experience and high engagement end-to-end
- Uplifting voices within teams and communities including providing strategy and structure to Employee Resource Group leads, organization design tactics, and programs that encourage collaboration on teams
- Building out mentorships programs aimed at maintaining positive company culture, helping job seekers land their dream roles, or knowledge share 
- Planning and running complex career development programming for future coders, business world trailblazers, and career transitioners
- Enacting strategic change or organizational transformation via change management strategies
- Listening deeply and helping others harness their intuitive creativity 
- Planning and championing wellness programs/initiatives for employees 
- Recruiting and onboarding talent 

Please reach out if you:
--> Are needing support, coaching, or mentorship in your job search
--> Are a talent development professional and want to share best practices for supporting the employee experience or job seekers

Other things you might want to know about me:
- I have a long term dream to start my own permaculture farm üçéü•¶üçâü•¨ . It would make my day to talk with you about gardening, agriculture, permaculture, or sustainable farming practices. 
- I am a singer-writer and I've grown up in a family of musicians. Songwriting helps me process the world around me.
- I do a lot of visual art (watercolor is my go-to medium right now)
- I'll do anything sports related and can be pretty competitive about it (swimming, running, climbing, yoga, soccer, volleyball, to name a few)
- I'm an Entertainer personality type ESFP

name: Jane Wei-Skillern
position:
Senior Fellow 
UC Berkeley Haas School of Business, Center for Social Sector Leadership
about:
Jane Wei-Skillern is a Senior Fellow at the Center for Social Sector Leadership at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business. Previously, she has served on the faculty at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, Harvard Business School (HBS), and London Business School. She has studied and published extensively on nonprofit networks for more than two decades.  She has also taught courses on social entrepreneurship, nonprofit strategy, and network leadership to MBAs and executives, and is the author and coauthor of dozens of publications, including journal articles and HBS and UC Berkeley Haas School of Business case studies. 

Her research on network leadership examines how social impact leaders, whether funders, board members, nonprofit executives or staff, that focus less on building their own institutions and instead invest to build trust based networks and a strong relational foundation in their communities can achieve dramatic gains in mission impact.  Four network principles of success that she has observed from studying leading edge nonprofit networks are:

1. Mission before Organization
2. Trust not Control
3. Humility not Brand
4. Constellations not Stars

Leaders that demonstrate these principles in their collaborative work are better able to build robust, enduring networks, which in turn, generate social impact more efficiently, effectively, and sustainably.   This research can be found at newnetworkleader.org.

For the past several years, Jane has taken a leave from teaching in the MBA classroom to focus on supporting social impact leaders in the field to grow their impact through networks.  She is frequently invited to present keynote speeches, webinars, and workshops to share her research on network leadership and to facilitate the development of trust based collaborations within organizations and communities. 

Specialties: social entrepreneurship, philanthropy, nonprofit strategy, leadership and management of social enterprises, nonprofit growth and management of multi-site nonprofits, nonprofit networks, network leadership.

More information about Jane's research and teaching can be found at:  newnetworkleader.org and https://haas.berkeley.edu/cssl/faculty/si-fellows-visiting-scholars/

publications.title: Cracking the Network Code: Four Principles for Grantmakers
publications.subtitle: GEO: Grantmakers for Effective Organizations
publications.description: GEO‚Äôs newest publication sets out to crack the code behind the network mystique. In fact, there is a method to working more efficiently and effectively through networks, and a critical first step for grantmakers is adopting a network mindset, which may require dramatic shifts in attitude and behavior for some. Cracking the Network Code outlines four principles that comprise the network mindset, illustrates the principles with a range of examples of networks that have achieved real results, and offers practical questions and recommendations to help grantmakers achieve the benefits and avoid common pitfalls of working through networks.

name: Ishani Basak
position:
Data Science and Applied Mathematics Double Major @ UC Berkeley |
Applied ML @ AMD-Xilinx
about: I am a fourth-year undergraduate student at UC Berkeley, pursuing dual majors in Data Science and Applied Mathematics. In addition to my studies, I work as an academic tutor, supporting students in their learning journey. My goal is to leverage my computational and analytical skills to tackle real-world challenges. I have enriched my expertise through various courses and certifications in Python, OOP, and AWS. This summer, I interned at AMD, focusing on generative AI software development. I am enthusiastic about exploring new opportunities in data science and AI and am open to job prospects upon my graduation next year.

name: Janet Lopez
position: Recent college graduate from UC Berkeley in Applied Mathematics seeking a position in finance and data analysis.
about:
I am a recent college graduate from UC Berkeley in Applied Mathematics seeking a position in finance and data analysis utilizing my analytical math skills and strong business communication skills. 

In pursuing my math degree, I developed skills in data science including R statistical analysis. I initiated study groups in order to more effectively master the materials. 

I originally gained my business communication skills working at my family's small business, Eden L Market, a Oaxacan market known for its authentic Latin foods, drinks, spices, and craftwork. I continued to apply my work ethic and skills in my most recent positions, working at the Counseling Center at Santa Monica College and Goldman School of Public Policy at UC Berkeley. 

During my transition from college, I have temporarily returned to work at Eden L Market as Department Manager, learning more about operating a small business, enhancing customer relationship, and improving my Spanish. I am working both independently and in teams, gaining leadership skills, and resolving customer and employee issues. 

I look forward to achieving a professional position that makes use of both my academic training and my practical business skills.

name: Kaitlin Smith
position: Graduate Data Scientist @ AstraZeneca
about: As a Data Scientist and AI Researcher at AstraZeneca, I leverage my expertise in statistics and machine learning to advance the field of immuno-oncology. With a strong academic foundation from UC Berkeley, where I studied statistics, I am passionate about applying data-driven approaches to uncover insights in real-world evidence and early phase clinical trial data, while also using data effectively and efficiently through Bayesian approaches. My work is dedicated to driving innovation in healthcare and improving patient outcomes through advanced analytical techniques and cutting-edge research.

experience.title: Data Science & AI Graduate
experience.description: Developed AI agent framework to reduce patient burden in patient reported outcomes (PROs). Developed a deep-learning modeling framework to find predictive biomarkers using contrastive learning in early phase clinical trials. I also optimized the framework for use with real world evidence (RWE). Conducted biomarker meta-analysis using Bayesian hierarchical modelling to inform biomarker strategy.

name: Aditya Shah
position: Senior ML Scientist @ Visa  ‚óè  Speaker at Google AI For Social Good
about:
I am an ambitious and innately curious individual with a passion for playing with data and creating ways to solve complex issues facing our environment and society. I firmly believe that computational solutions are the next frontier. I am characterized from my unyielding appetite for learning new things, constantly setting and achieving complex goals, and creating opportunities to apply my newfound knowledge in innovative ways. I hold myself responsible to always strive for greatness, whether building new relationships, or leading the next frontier in computational solutions.

‚ô¶ My passion for data and AI is exemplified by utilizing Google's open-source machine learning library TensorFlow to invent a Smart Wildfire Sensor. The technology helps predict wildfires by analyzing images of the dead fuel accumulated in the forest in conjunction with other environmental factors.

‚ô¶ My invention has been become globally recognized by Governments, NGOs, and tech giants, like Google. It has been my privilege to participate in the AI panel discussion at the ‚ÄúGoogle AI for Social Good,‚Äù a $25M global initiative to fund similar projects to mitigate climate change and natural disasters. 

‚ô¶ As a result of my efforts and expertise in the field, I have had the honor of speaking at multiple Google AI events globally, including the US and Sweden.

I have graduated as a Regents' and Chancellor's Scholar with a degree in Computer Science from UC Berkeley

recommendations: Joyce J. Shen ‚ÄúI advised Aditya and his team on an AI project called Poliwatch, which is focused on using massive amount of data to help understand trading activities of Congressional members. The team worked with limited resources but built a state-of-art data science project leveraging advanced techniques. Aditya is a key contributor to this project, and I am excited to see him taking his talent further to make big impacts on the world!‚Äù

Kevin Hartman ‚ÄúI had the pleasure of serving as Aditya Shah's data science capstone advisor at UC Berkeley, and I am delighted to endorse him as an exceptional data scientist. Aditya's capstone project, PoliWatch, is an AI-driven watchdog tool designed to assist journalists in researching potential conflicts of interest in the publicly disclosed stock transactions of congressional members. Aditya played a pivotal role in the project as the team's Machine Learning Engineer. He spearheaded the development of the Retriever architecture, a key component designed for retrieving and matching relevant information across disparate data sources by converting the data into vectorized embeddings using an LLM. Aditya's technical expertise and focused approach were instrumental in the success of the project. His sharp intellect and unwavering focus were evident throughout the project, showcasing both his technical prowess and commitment to achieving excellence. Aditya and his team went above and beyond, not only in delivering an effective presentation but also in producing a complete and well-scoped product, demonstrating their dedication to the entire project lifecycle. Aditya's ability to contribute meaningfully to the team, coupled with his technical skills, make him stand out as a remarkable data scientist. It was a pleasure working with Aditya, and I am confident that he will continue to make significant contributions in the field of data science. I highly recommend Aditya Shah to any organization seeking a talented and focused professional in the realm of data science.‚Äù

Fourth-year undergraduate at UC Berkeley, double majoring in Computer Science and Data Science.

Currently, I am a researcher under Prof. Joseph Gonzalez, contributing to the Berkeley Function Calling Leaderboard Project as part of the Gorilla LLM initiative.

Previously, I‚Äôve held Data Scientist and Software Engineering intern roles at Novelis (the world‚Äôs largest producer of flat-rolled aluminum products) and Archonet (NVIDIA Inception Batch 2023). Additionally, I conducted research under Prof. Brent Fulton at the Berkeley Petris Center and Michael DeBellis at DaanMatch.

I‚Äôm eager to take on fast-paced ML and Data Science roles, where I can apply my expertise in machine learning, data engineering, and AI-driven systems.

name: Jennifer Ortega
position: Data Science & Cognitive Science Graduate at University of California, Berkeley | Prev Data Science Intern at Kaiser Permanente
about:
Passionate about data-driven insights and enhancing user experiences, I'm a Data Science enthusiast with a strong foundation in predictive modeling and statistical analysis.

As a recent graduate with a double major in Data Science and Cognitive Science from UC Berkeley, I've developed comprehensive AI solutions and automation tools at Convergent Computing, while also creating predictive models at Kaiser Permanente to analyze mobile app usage patterns across 3 million members. I've demonstrated expertise in process optimization by implementing Tableau dashboards tracking 200+ processes and leading GitHub implementation projects.

Proficient in Python, SAS, Azure AI services, and cross-functional collaboration, I'm dedicated to leveraging data to drive informed decisions and optimize user interactions. I am deeply enthusiastic about harnessing the power of data to drive meaningful insights and enhance user experiences. By blending technical expertise with strong analytical skills, I'm committed to refining user experiences and driving data-informed strategies.

Open to new opportunities, collaborations, and growth in the data science field.

current_company.name: Kaiser Permanente
current_company.title: Data Science & Cognitive Science Graduate at University of California, Berkeley | Prev Data Science Intern at Kaiser Permanente

experience.title: Data Science Intern
experience.description: Created Tableau dashboard tracking 200+ processes for Advanced Analytics Automation team, monitoring run frequencies, run statuses, dependencies, and error reports. Implemented SAS script to extract and compile information from log paths for comprehensive dashboard reporting. Improved team efficiency through streamlined process tracking and error reporting. Led GitHub implementation project, migrating code from SAS to specific repositories for each Experience Group (EG). Authored user guide on branch creation and merging; established roles and backups for each EG.

Gained hands-on experience with Azure Data Factory, PostgreSQL, AI Search, and Azure Machine Learning.
