name: Ollie Downs
position: Senior Data and Research Analyst at the County of San Diego
about:
As a graduate of the UC Berkeley Master of Information and Data Science, I am proud to have a wealth of expertise in data analytics, visualization, stewardship, and more. My time at Cal gave me a solid knowledge foundation as well as a complex, diverse lexicon surrounding WHY DATA MATTERS. 

In addition to using my training in data science and analytics, I constantly examine the human side of data. Data stewardship, privacy, ethics, and contextualization of data are not only concepts to me, but skills and experience that I actively practice. I am excited to demonstrate my understanding of HOW DATA WORKS as well as HOW INFORMATION FUELS DECISIONS AND PROGRESS. 

My experiences cover the entire data life cycle ‚Äì I've worked with information that begins on paper and ends with decision-making at all levels of organizations. This background, alongside my dedication to humanity as it interacts with data, allows me to draw insightful conclusions about the world, my organizations, and the data in front of me. I love puzzling and problem-solving, especially when it comes to WHAT MAKES DATA HAPPEN. 

My work history has given me insight into a broad range of communities and diversity in interests. I am committed to promoting equity and justice, and as a queer/trans person, I understand the importance of asking WHO IS THE STAKEHOLDER.

I'm proud to say that I have explored many opportunities throughout COVID. Having graduated into a pandemic, I've evolved alongside the WFH culture and the challenges that come with it. I am finally settling into my positionality as a data professional, and am excited to see what challenges and insights exist in my future.

experience.title: Data Analyst
experience.description: ‚Ä¢ Manages progress on multiple projects at a time, utilizing Trello, Lucidchart, Zoom, and the Microsoft Suite to ideate, visualize, communicate, and publicize workflows and results for stakeholders.‚Ä¢ Works in tandem with Covalent's Data Architect to answer complex business questions with reusable, reproducible reports, metrics, and visualizations. ‚Ä¢ Takes responsibility for data stewardship while Covalent shifts from an information-aware to a data-driven organization.‚Ä¢ Upkeeps a server of 60+ Tableau reports, ensuring accuracy and accessibility of files while streamlining information flow and load times to enable efficiency in users' daily tasks.‚Ä¢ Solves urgent business challenges daily and performs ad-hoc analyses for both leadership teams and personnel on the ground.

publications.title: AI on the Edge with Security: Foundations and Practices
publications.subtitle: Springer
publications.description: This book provides readers with an overview of the next generation of Cloud computing with AI, evolving to minimize latency and address privacy/security concerns of many customers. This book will highlight the associated problems and propose new solutions for performing AI and ML at the Edge of computing networks.

publications.title: RFC 5140 - A Telephony Gateway REgistration Protocol (TGREP)
publications.subtitle: Internet Engineering Task Force
publications.description: This document RFC-5140 describes the Telephony Gateway Registration Protocol (TGREP) for registration of telephony prefixes supported by telephony gateways and soft switches. The registration mechanism can also be used to export resource information. The prefix and resource information can then be passed on to a Telephony Routing over IP (TRIP) Location Server, which in turn can propagate that routing information within and between Internet Telephony Administrative Domains (ITADs). TGREP shares a lot of similarities with the TRIP protocol. It has similar procedures and finite state machine for session establishment. It also shares the same format for messages and a subset of attributes with TRIP.

publications.title: The BUCKY Object Relational Benchmark by David Dewitt, Jeffrey Naughton, Michael Carey, Dhaval N. Shah, Johannes Gehrke and Mohammed Asgarian
publications.subtitle: Proceedings of the 1997 ACM SIGMOD international conference on Management of data
publications.description: According to various trade journals and corporate marketing machines, we are now on the verge of a revolution - the object-relational database revolution. Since we believe that no one should face a revolution without appropriate armaments, this paper presents BUCKY, a new benchmark for object relational database systems. BUCKY is a query oriented benchmark that tests many of the key features offered by object-relational systems, including row types and inheritance, references and path expressions, sets of atomic values and of references, methods and late binding and user-defined abstract data types and their methods. To test the maturity of object-relational technology relative to relational technology, we provide both an object-relational version of BUCKY and a relational equivalent thereof (ie. a relational BUCKY simulation). Finally, we briefly discuss the initial performance results and lessons that resulted from applying BUCKY to one of the early object-relational database system products.

name: Ned Resnikoff
position: Urbanist, Writer, Policy Analyst
about:
I am an analyst, researcher, journalist, and consultant with 15 years of experience navigating some of America‚Äôs most complex policy challenges. I‚Äôve worked on everything from K-12 education to health care, but my primary focus is housing and overlapping areas of urban policy. I am currently a housing policy fellow at the Roosevelt Institute and a member of the EQ Collaborative.

I was previously the policy director for California YIMBY (‚ÄúYes in My Backyard‚Äù), which is working to end California‚Äôs housing crisis through state-level policy change. Prior to that, I served as policy manager for the UCSF Benioff Housing and Homelessness Initiative, an academic institute that researches and advocates for evidence-based strategies to end homelessness. I have also worked as a fiscal and policy advisor to the California state legislature.

In addition, I‚Äôm a seasoned journalist and editor with bylines in The New York Times, msnbc.com, The New Republic, The San Francisco Chronicle, and various other publications. I‚Äôm currently working on a book about cities for Island Press, with an expected publication date of Fall 2026.

I hold a Masters in Public Policy from UC Berkeley‚Äôs Goldman School of Public Policy. I live in the East Bay with my wife, daughter, and cat.

name: Gladys Valencia
position: Recent UC Berkeley graduate | Aspiring Analytics Professional
about:
I am a young professional focused on growing in the field of analytics, and a creative problem solver with a strong analytical mind. My coursework, projects, and teaching experience during my undergraduate years at UC Berkeley have helped me grow. 

Teaching an adjunct group of 20 students from diverse backgrounds three times a week, with the UC Berkeley Student Learning Center, allowed me to expand my communication and interpersonal skills, and also to develop a deeper appreciation for people‚Äôs different viewpoints.  Working with others, be it preparing a lesson plan with another adjunct instructor or simply working together with other drop-in tutors to answer student questions, has taught me the beauty and power of collaboration. 

Traits like these have helped me make a significant impact in the environment I have worked in. As a recent graduate seeking a full-time position, I would love to find the right company/organization to which I could contribute using my skill set. I would be more than happy to connect with other professionals in this field, and am open to internship and externship opportunities.

experience.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
experience.description: Research topic: PADOs AI Integration Project Professor: Bertozzi, Stefano M.Lab manager: Jorge Antonio Morales AlfaroAccess to quality healthcare remains a pressing issue in Mexico, where public health services are underfunded and overburdened. In response, many low-income communities have turned to Pharmacy-Adjacent Doctor Offices (PADOs)‚Äîsmall medical offices attached to pharmacies‚Äîas an alternative for primary care. However, research on the quality, equity, and long-term health impact of these private services remains scarce.As a Research Assistant at UC Berkeley‚Äôs School of Public Health, I am leveraging AI and data science to bridge this gap. My work involves developing AI models that automate key insights extraction and trend identification from healthcare-related research, helping to assess the accessibility and effectiveness of PADOs. Additionally, I am building and refining data pipelines and utilizing Google Places APIs to systematically collect, integrate, and validate PADO data from multiple sources, ensuring its accuracy and usability for public health analysis.
experience.description_html:
Research topic: PADOs AI Integration Project
Professor: Bertozzi, Stefano M.
Lab manager: Jorge Antonio Morales Alfaro

Access to quality healthcare remains a pressing issue in Mexico, where public health services are underfunded and overburdened. In response, many low-income communities have turned to Pharmacy-Adjacent Doctor Offices (PADOs)—small medical offices attached to pharmacies—as an alternative for primary care. However, research on the quality, equity, and long-term health impact of these private services remains scarce.

As a Research Assistant at UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health, I am leveraging AI and data science to bridge this gap. My work involves developing AI models that automate key insights extraction and trend identification from healthcare-related research, helping to assess the accessibility and effectiveness of PADOs. Additionally, I am building and refining data pipelines and utilizing Google Places APIs to systematically collect, integrate, and validate PADO data from multiple sources, ensuring its accuracy and usability for public health analysis.
experience.company: UC Berkeley School of Public Health

experience.title: Financial Wellness Coach
experience.description: Access to a free financial wellness advisor in school is crucial for students to cultivate healthy financial habits that can set them up for a secure future. In the position, I get the honor to work with students one-on-one to assess their financial situation and give them guidance with money management skills, spending plans, and fostering responsible financial decision-making which not only benefits their own financial well-being, but also contributes to the economic stability of the people around them. The Center for Financial Wellness hosts Dollars for Scholars program for 50+ students to meet with a peer and discuss campus recourses and healthy financial habits. Additionally, we host virtual and in-person workshops for students to attend to learn more about financial wellness topics like credit and savings, budgeting, and more.

experience.title: Business Analyst Intern
experience.description: During my internship at SOLO Intellectual Property Management, I had the opportunity to delve into the evolving intersection of intellectual property (IP), Web3, and blockchain technology. My role primarily focused on conducting comprehensive market analysis on IP lenders, reviewing data on NFT loan providers, and assessing their potential integration within the IP as collateral landscape.Additionally, I played a key role in creating and presenting strategic pitch presentations focusing on product differentiation and increasing market positioning and brand resonance to support the company's Initial Coin Offering (ICO) efforts in the broader blockchain environment. This experience not only enhanced my analytical and research skills but also deepened my understanding of the innovative ways in which IP can be leveraged in the digital economy.

experience.description: In this position, I had the opportunity to streamline and enhance the efficiency of financial processes. I developed 10 Excel Macros that significantly improved bookkeeping efficiency by automating the conversion of over 200 rental reservation invoices into QuickBooks templates.In addition to process automation, I conducted detailed financial analyses of data from 90+ chapters, providing critical insights to the CFO on potential money mismanagement and reconciliation issues. This position allowed me to apply and further develop my skills in financial analysis, data automation, and operational efficiency, contributing to the overall financial health and accountability of the organization.

experience.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
experience.description: Research topic: Workplace Schadenfreude Lab: Haas Intersectionality, Group Hierarchy, Emotion Research (HIGHER) Lab at Haas School of Business, University of California, BerkeleyProfessor: Dr. Sa-Kiera TJ HudsonLab manager: Daniel SanjiResearching workplace schadenfreude, which is essentially finding joy in the misfortunes of others in the context of work, is important for businesses because it helps them create a more positive and productive environment. By understanding how it affects employees and team dynamics, companies can take steps to prevent it from harming morale and creating a toxic workplace culture. This research can guide the implementation of strategies that promote empathy, collaboration, and a healthier overall atmosphere for workplaces.
experience.description_html:
Research topic: Workplace Schadenfreude
Lab: Haas Intersectionality, Group Hierarchy, Emotion Research (HIGHER) Lab at Haas School of Business, University of California, Berkeley
Professor: Dr. Sa-Kiera TJ Hudson
Lab manager: Daniel Sanji

Researching workplace schadenfreude, which is essentially finding joy in the misfortunes of others in the context of work, is important for businesses because it helps them create a more positive and productive environment. By understanding how it affects employees and team dynamics, companies can take steps to prevent it from harming morale and creating a toxic workplace culture. This research can guide the implementation of strategies that promote empathy, collaboration, and a healthier overall atmosphere for workplaces.

experience.title: Electrical Engineering Intern
experience.description: During my internship, I gained hands-on experience in managing and executing complex projects that balanced technical precision with client needs. I drafted detailed specifications for electrical additions, ensuring they met both the functional and aesthetic requirements of the clients, like a sheet metal conduit covering for the Sunnyvale Community Center.I also developed data visualizations, including Gantt Charts to monitor project timelines and time series charts to understand energy efficiency and usage across various California courthouses. One of my key projects involved collaborating with Aedis Architects on a $150k initiative to design the electrical infrastructure for Chabot College's temporary biology lab, ensuring it would serve as a fully functional swing space for students.

This approach not only boosted total sales but also fostered stronger customer loyalty, helping to build a positive and welcoming environment for our patrons.

name: Luka Cheney
position: Data Science and Cognitive Science at University of California, Berkeley | Graduated May 2024
about:
Hi! My name is Luka Cheney and I am a recent graduate of UC Berkeley where I double majored in Data/Computer Science (emphasis Computational Biology) and Cognitive Science (emphasis in Neuroscience).

I am experienced in coding with Python, SQL, Java, Excel, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. I am currently working on getting AWS certified and researching various Neural Network applications. I love leveraging my knowledge in statistics and my visualization abilities to perform meaningful data analysis projects as well. On top of my coding experience, I took as many Neuroscience and Genetics classes as possible at UC Berkeley. This has allowed me to work on many bioinformatics and biotech projects. I hope to one day get my masters in Bioinformatics, but until then, I am happy to work in any sector with Data Science or Software Engineering.

I am versatile, hard-working, and always looking to learn more about my field. Please feel free to contact me at lukajcheney@gmail.com for any professional inquiries!

experience.title: Data Scientist/Software Engineer
experience.description: ‚Ä¢ Designed and implemented database and data collection protocols for collecting chemistry trial data.‚Ä¢ Programmed apps in JavaScript that allow chemists in lab to clean data, perform data analysis, and export/import data sheets from the database. Data is stored in a format that allows it to later train Machine Learning models.‚Ä¢ Collaborated with PLC Engineer to set up a system where data is read from chemical sensors every 5 minutes and is sent to the in-lab chemist‚Äôs google spreadsheet account in real time.
experience.description_html:
• Designed and implemented database and data collection protocols for collecting chemistry trial data.

• Programmed apps in JavaScript that allow chemists in lab to clean data, perform data analysis, and export/import data sheets from the database. Data is stored in a format that allows it to later train Machine Learning models.

• Collaborated with PLC Engineer to set up a system where data is read from chemical sensors every 5 minutes and is sent to the in-lab chemist’s google spreadsheet account in real time.

Scheduled to run every morning, leveraging GCP‚Äôs virtual servers for processing.‚Ä¢ Designed software that calculates fire danger ratings based on government compliant algorithms.‚Ä¢ Research and implement state-of-the-art Neural Network and Machine Learning techniques to predict daily weather data 3 months into the future. Built models for 5 weather variables and optimized via hyperparameter tuning.
experience.description_html:
• Developed an automated pipeline that downloads government weather data and stores it in our company’s Google Cloud Platform (GCP) storage. Scheduled to run every morning, leveraging GCP’s virtual servers for processing.

• Designed software that calculates fire danger ratings based on government compliant algorithms.

• Research and implement state-of-the-art Neural Network and Machine Learning techniques to predict daily weather data 3 months into the future. Built models for 5 weather variables and optimized via hyperparameter tuning.

name: Andrew Chen
position: UC Berkeley ‚Äô25 | Political Science, Psychology, & Data Science
about:
Hello! I‚Äôm Andrew, a fifth-year undergraduate pursuing a double major in Political Science (with Highest Honors) and Psychology and a minor in Data Science at the University of California, Berkeley. I am currently studying abroad at the School of Psychology at the University of Padua until July 2025.

I am passionate about studying the intersections between politics, psychology, data, and education. In particular, I am interested in researching the psychosocial factors that influence public opinion, especially biases, social pressure, and the lack of accurate information, through laboratory and field experiments.

Outside of my own academics and research, I‚Äôm committed to empowering students to accomplish their personal and academic ambitions by ensuring that all students are well-equipped with the resources they need to succeed through my work with multiple student organizations, the Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC), the College of Computing, Data Science, and Society (CDSS), and the Student Learning Center (SLC) at UC Berkeley.

Please feel free to contact me through LinkedIn or at andrew_chen04 [at] berkeley [dot] edu!

name: Sophia Dumesny
position: Student at UC Berkeley | Double major in Global Management Program under Haas School of Business
about:
I am currently a senior at UC Berkeley double majoring in Business Administration with a concentration in Global Management and French. 

My peers and instructors have described me as a positive, hardworking, passionate, and open-minded individual who is eager to learn and is not afraid of a challenge. I have been awarded certificates in compassion, integrity, group leadership, and for my analytical writing skills.

I have a wide variety of interests including sustainability, journalism, and marketing on a global scale. I enjoy working in a cross-cultural environment. I will graduate in May of 2024 in hopes of pursuing a career in one of these fields. I look forward to acquiring new skills and building a professional network.

name: Shreya Gupta
position: Data Sci Honors & Comp Sci @ UC Berkeley
about:
Portfolio: https://shreyagxpta.github.io/

As a passionate and results-driven Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley, I specialize in Data Sci & Analytics, AI/ML, and software development. My expertise spans data-driven problem-solving, algorithmic modeling, and scalable software systems. Through my work as a TA, researcher, and intern, I have honed my ability to analyze complex datasets, build intelligent systems, and communicate technical insights effectively. My research involvement in equity-focused STEM initiatives further reflects my commitment to leveraging technology for social impact. Dedicated to bridging theoretical knowledge with real-world applications, I am eager to contribute my skills in data science, AI, NLP, and SWE to forward-thinking organizations.

recommendations: Angela Maiers ‚ÄúElana is a very passionate and gifted educator dedicated to this mission heart and soul. She loves what she does and it shows in her attitude and work ethic. Her contribution to Edutopia has helped and inspired thousands of teachers to stay connected, stay passionate, and stay in the profession. She is an asset to any team or collaborative effort. ‚Äù

Thomas Whitby ‚ÄúI have been working professionally with Edutopia and Elana Leoni for several years now. I have found Elana to be a consummate professional (a clich√©, but still appropriate) in regard to social media in its varied forms. Her knowledge and experience of social media have been able to maximize information in answer to any of my requests. Her personal demeanor of calm confidence has always served her well in assuring people that she was the definitive ‚Äúgo to person‚Äù to resolve their problem. If Elana didn‚Äôt have the answer, she knew who would and would follow through with a solution or at the very least an answer. Elana‚Äôs position with Edutopia has placed her in a position to be networked with many of the most influential thought leaders in education. This has given her the ability to connect many people who would otherwise not be connected. Additionally it has educated her to the needs, desires, and solutions offered by educators on a global scale. I would without hesitation recommend Elana Leoni for any position that she felt qualified to apply for. Her maturity, professionalism, and demeanor place her heads and shoulders above many of her contemporaries. Her Social Media experience is both extensive and relevant, which is a rare combination in today‚Äôs fast paced changing world. In our technology-driven society a candidate like Elana Leoni is a rare find and will be an asset to any company fortunate enough to find her. ‚Äù

name: Julia Dawson
position: Business Student at University of California, Berkeley
about:
As a third-year business student at UC Berkeley Haas, I am passionate about strategy consulting, finance and economics. I have honed my skills through my coursework, professional experience, and extracurricular leadership positions over the past three years. 

Most recently, I served as the Vice President of Projects at Muses Consulting Studio where I facilitate professional partnerships and projects between UC Berkeley consulting organizations and industry clients in the tech sector. Additionally, I am an economics tutor at the University of California, Berkeley Student Learning Center, where I offer specialized support to my peers and promote collaborative learning. 

I am eager to connect with like-minded individuals, please feel free to reach out to me!
Connect with me at juliasdawson@berkeley.edu

          Clarity is a nonprofit social platform aimed at teaching personal financial literacy, professional recruiting, and college admissions to help level the playing field for disadvantaged families.Last year, I spearheaded a college mentorship program where we paired high school seniors with mentors at their dream schools. This resulted in students getting accepted into elite universities nationwide such as Carnegie Mellon, UC Berkeley, Georgetown University, University of Michigan, and UT Austin. Additionally, we've taught over 100 low-income students and families about financial literacy through 2+ workshops and speaker series per month. In just 4 months, Clarity's content and resources on personal financial literacy and professional recruiting garnered ~24,000 post impressions and helped it reach ~270 followers.We're actively seeking partnerships and trying to grow our reach! Feel free to reach out to me or askclarityofficial@gmail.com for business inquiries or additional information.
            

    
    

    
        Show less

          Boost @ Berkeley Haas prepares and supports students throughout their high school journey through various workshops that focus on college preparedness, life skills development, professional development, case study projects and mentorship.I personally joined the 9th-grade mentorship team this fall and have led a group of ~8 high school freshmen in developing a strategic recommendation for OakLuv, a nonprofit focused on gift-giving to underprivileged communities during the holiday season. To develop this recommendation, I helped the group analyze Oakluv‚Äôs current social media efforts, examining platforms, content, and timing of posts. After the preliminary research, I guided the students' development of a final PowerPoint presentation to showcase their comprehensive strategy recommendation which aims to increase Oakluv‚Äôs awareness, event frequency, and volunteer participation.

Combining that information with over 175 interviews of college students and‚Ä¶
            

    
    

    
        Show more

          
    
  
      

        
          Heylo is a messaging startup that aims to help people to find and foster emotional connections within large groups.Working directly for the founders, I was tasked with developing a go-to-market strategy for Heylo to launch on UC Berkeley's campus. First, I cross-examined Heylo's platform with other's in the large-group messaging space to determine key differentiators that separated Heylo from the competition. Combining that information with over 175 interviews of college students and startups that have successfully launched at Berkeley, I was able to provide Heylo with not just a strategy to launch at Berkeley's campus as soon as Fall 2020, but also several feature recommendations for Heylo to better serve the college community and retain the traction they make.Update: The plan for Heylo to build a virtual recruiting tool into their platform (leveraging virtual curriculum due to the COVID-19 pandemic) was able to land them traction not just at UC Berkeley, but more than 20 colleges across the nation the next semester (fall 2020)
            

    
    

    
        Show less

          Thrive DC is a nonprofit organization based in Washington D.C. that serves over 150,000 meals to local homeless citizens each year. I volunteered at the D.C. location for over 15 hours each month. During my 6-hour shifts as a volunteer, I aided in the preparation, cooking, and distribution of meals to more than 300 homeless D.C. citizens. After the food service, I led the volunteers in the cleaning of the dining hall, kitchen, and showers. On the administrative side, I helped draft promotional materials using PowerPoint, Mailchimp, and Photoshop which increased attendance by over 15%. I also marketed to my football teammates, colleagues, and family members, resulting in over 20 new regular volunteers.

organizations.title: Paradigm Consulting
organizations.description: Founded in 2003, Paradigm Consulting is a nonprofit, student-run strategy consulting organization that operates as the consulting arm of the professional organization Alpha Epsilon Zeta at the University of California, Berkeley. Paradigm Consulting develops cutting-edge, applicable solutions for clients varying from Fortune 500 companies to early-stage startups that are leaders in each of their respective industries.Paradigm‚Äôs consultants are extremely driven individuals who come from a diverse range of majors. These students were selected amidst a rigorous recruiting cycle before going through a challenging development process crafted with guidance from the Haas School of Business and industry mentors. Past clients include AWS, eBay, Bose, and more.I personally led teams of 5 consultants as a project leader for strategy projects with HP and Mosaic after initially working as a product strategy consultant for Roblox.

organizations.title: Alpha Epsilon Zeta Professional Fraternity
organizations.description: Alpha Epsilon Zeta (AEZ) is an undergraduate professional fraternity at the University of California, Berkeley. AEZ distinguishes itself from traditional professional fraternities by embracing a multidisciplinary focus. The brothers of AEZ come from a wide variety of majors, ranging from biology to business to engineering, and each brother strives to be well-versed in all aspects of every academic discipline. We are dedicated to promoting and fostering professionalism, brotherhood, unity, and tradition.As Internal Vice President, I scheduled weekly meeting itineraries and socials for the brotherhood of 40+. I also organized external alumni panels with guest speakers from Apple, Google, Morgan Stanley, and more for the broader Berkeley community. Additionally, I helped transform current recruitment strategies by incorporating social media marketing & networking events, resulting in a 300% applicant increase

          Start.coop is an accelerator for shared ownership businesses. It is a promising program to help grow the co-op movement and share wealth and power equitably. In 2018 I completed research and produced a plan for mobilizing aligned capital by creating an accelerator program, which helped inform the creation of Start. I also helped develop its core 12-week program to scale co-op enterprises and platforms, primarily by reviewing potential participants and doing in-depth interviews with the 2019 and 2020 cohorts. In 2021 I contributed to a 3-year project to create a "Lean Co-op" course, and also created an "Ownership Model Canvas" to help startups align their purpose with who owns their business.

activity.title: I'm excited to share that I‚Äôll be joining Global Key Advisors as a Quantitative Intern for Summer 2025! I am excited to deepen my experience in‚Ä¶
My relationship with data science has evolved a lot since I started at Berkeley. As a freshman, I felt that there were negative stigmas regarding the‚Ä¶
13 years ago, my third-grade teacher asked me, ‚ÄúWhat do you want to be when you grow up?‚Äù I replied, ‚ÄúA software engineer at Google.‚Äù Little did I‚Ä¶
I am excited to share that I will be serving as a Legislative Intern in Congresswoman Doris Matsui‚Äôs office this summer in Sacramento! It is truly an‚Ä¶

name: Ashley Madera
position: Sociology and Public Policy At UC Berkeley College of Letters and Sciences
about:
Hi! My name is Ashley Madera, and I am a current student at the University of California, Berkeley. 

I have a keen interest in law, business, and communications. I seek to combine these interests into my future pursuits and career aspirations. My dedication extends to advocating for educational equity, advancing social justice, and encouraging Latine excellence in higher education. 

I have a profound love for learning and will continue to make strides as I ignite conversations, immerse in business ventures, and promote equitable resources to uplift communities.  

Outside of academics, you can see me exploring new places and fostering relationships with such a diverse and passionate group of people, yourself included! I am open to new opportunities or connections. Let's continue to drive meaningful conversations and empower change, growth, and inclusivity into our society. Thank you!

publications.subtitle: <AI & Equality>
publications.description: This comment addresses questions of transparency, human rights, and stakeholder involvement put forth by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA). We urge the NTIA to consider AI accountability through a framework of human rights. First, we address transparency & accountability through the perspective of due process. Then, we provide information on the ‚Äúright to know‚Äù, urging that AI accountability measures include the requirement that individuals should be notified when an automated decision has been made about them. Finally, we conclude with information and suggestions for stakeholder involvement, a part of AI accountability that we believe to be unwaveringly necessary.

publications.title: Enabling Input on Tiny/Headless Systems Using Morse Code
publications.subtitle: arXiv
publications.description: This paper presents results of a pilot study that explored the potential of Morse code as a method for text entry on mobile devices. In the study, participants without prior experience with Morse code reached 6.7 wpm with a Morse code keyboard in three short sessions. Learning was observed both in terms of text entry speed and accuracy, which suggests that the overall performance of the keyboard is likely to improve with practice.

experience.title: Elementary School Tutor
experience.description: Working in Fremont Elementary in Fresno, CA - a predominately Black and Latinx student population - we were understaffed, under-resourced, and underfunded. Students had no access to computers, equipment was either missing or broken and often found no chairs to even sit the students. In a job that first seemed impossible, I later established love and respect for the students and their parents. Before leaving, I used my own money to create a Christmas party with food, utensils, and prizes for the children.

name: Katie Weber
position:
Critical thinker. Persuasive writer.
Lead Strategist at Think Deeply, Write Clearly, LLC.
about:
I had originally considered pursuing a psychology major as an undergraduate at UC Berkeley, but my professors kindly suggested to me that people who ask the question ‚Äúwhy‚Äù enough are less suited toward psychology as they are for other fields, such as philosophy. So, I made that switch, entirely anticipating that I would pursue a career either in academia (which I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily enjoy), or law (which I may have enjoyed, but I couldn‚Äôt afford to pay for law school). 

However, I ultimately became very passionate about the movement of information itself and the effective presentation of ideas, which motivated me to take my writing very seriously and, more specifically, to accept a leadership position at Think Deeply, Write Clearly.

Here's the thing that I learned along the way, and accordingly, why I‚Äôm highly passionate about the work I‚Äôm doing now:
If we ask ‚Äúwhy‚Äù enough, if we investigate ideas to their core, there is an actionable assessment somewhere. In other words, there is a depth of information that is reliably consistent from which we can then make informed decisions. This is the actionable piece of information that not only a client needs to know about a business that is providing services (e.g., why the client should hire you rather than the other people in this space), but also the actionable piece of advice each of us need in all areas of life, in order to foster better cultural discussions, better academic discussions, better connections in our relationships and in our careers.

My purpose is to build relationships and investigate ideas with as many of the thoughtful people I can here on LinkedIn. 

If that investigation sounds interesting to you, please accept this open invitation to an introductory chat‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to learn more about you and your business, and develop a relationship through LinkedIn with you.

name: Lea Baechler-Brabo

about:
Experienced education professional guiding students and families on the path to college and career through exploration, experience, expertise and excellent planning. Founder of Great Choices College Advising. www.greatchoicescollege.com 

Active member of the Higher Education Consultants Association (HECA) committed to providing my students with the highest level of service, upholding the ethics and principles of my profession, and staying informed on all the latest developments in college admissions and career planning.

experience.title: Independent Educational Consultant
experience.description: Guide and support high school students on their path to college through academic planning, self-exploration, and college research that is engaging, focused, and organized into manageable steps. My goal is for students to understand more fully why they want to go to college and what matters to them so that they are prepared and ready to put forward strong applications to the "best fit" colleges that offer them a learning community where they can thrive. When students start asking the right questions, and become engaged and motivated, they find that the path to life after high school is full of great choices.

name: Elliott Medrich
position: Education Data and Policy Analysis Consulting
about:
I have been an education researcher and policy analyst for my entire professional career. Areas of expertise include:

‚Ä¢	Designing performance measurement, accountability, and benchmarking systems
‚Ä¢	Conducting statistical analysis of longitudinal and cross-sectional databases 
‚Ä¢	Designing and analyzing surveys, and developing research logic models
‚Ä¢	Conducting program evaluations (both qualitative and quantitative)

Essential elements of my work have included writing proposals and budgets for federal and state government contracting, foundations and non-profit grant makers; designing and implementing detailed project management and performance-based reporting systems; and building multi-organization research partnerships. 

I have extensive experience in hiring, managing, training, and mentoring research and administrative staff at all levels.

I have authored many peer-reviewed journal articles and books on daily life in childhood, attributes of student learning and student outcomes, and teacher coaching and professional development.

name: Marc Bacani

about:
Consultant and team leader with 15 years of experience working with nonprofits, political campaigns, and global organizations, including advising a Fortune 50 client. Skilled in managing cross-functional teams, leading stakeholder engagement, and driving complex projects from strategy to execution. Experienced in policy analysis, strategic planning, and business process improvement, with a focus on adapting stakeholder strategies across diverse regional markets. Known for empathetic leadership, operational insight, and a creative mindset shaped by passions for photography, film, and music.

That love for structure spills into my home life too. Whether it‚Äôs organizing a cabinet full of spices or untangling a drawer full of charging cables, I‚Äôm wired to believe there‚Äôs always a slightly better way to do things ‚Äî something that improves quality, reduces friction, and saves time.

Always open to thoughtful conversations ‚Äî especially around strategy, storytelling, and systems that actually work. I also get excited to discuss plant care, the NBA, and curating the perfect playlist. Let‚Äôs connect!

organizations.title: Blacks in Public Policy (BiPP)
organizations.description: BiPP's mission is to encourage the discussion of public policy issues as they relate to the Black community. We coordinate mentorship programs for UC Berkeley undergraduates, host film screenings and discussions, and volunteer collectively in the local community. BIPP also provides a social network for African American students at GSPP through social gatherings and team building activities.

organizations.title: Students of Color in Public Policy (SCiPP)
organizations.membership_type: Peer Advising Program Manager | Steering Committee Member
organizations.description: SCiPP's mission is to ensure the serious consideration of issues of racial and ethnic diversity in policy design. SCiPP provides a support network for students of color at the Goldman School of Public Policy (GSPP) and a forum for discussion of policy implications for people of color. The group holds a number of programmatic events throughout the year. This includes organizing the annual Race and Policy Symposium and coordinating the SCiPP Peer Advising Program.

name: Akilah Favors
position: PhD Student at UC Berkeley| Undergraduate Program Director| DEIB Coding Consultant
about:
I am a sociologist who examines social inequality, race, political mobilization, urban development and culture. My research investigates activists‚Äô efforts to curtail systemic racism, transform political spheres of exclusion, and institutionalize radical diversity. At Spelman College, I explored protests for racial-ethnic inclusion in Argentina and South Africa. As a UC Berkeley PhD student, I work as an academic researcher, organizational coding specialist, and undergraduate program director to identify and implement strategies that increase feelings of belonging, amplify equity, and achieve social justice for marginal groups. My goal is to merge my doctoral training in sociology with my assessments of DEIB in international businesses across sectors to inform sustainable social change in collegiate and corporate institutions. 

My skills entail teaching, project management, professional development, qualitative research methods (survey, interview, and participant observation) and grant writing. I received my B.A. in Sociology from Spelman College and my M.A. in Sociology from the University of California, Berkeley. I also completed the field-based Social Movements Program in Buenos Aires, Argentina with the School for International Training.

positions.subtitle: CenterFocus International, Inc.
positions.description: I currently work as a lead qualitative data coding specialist for an international study seeking to measure the impact of Chief Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Officers across a range of sectors such as technology, law, corporate, medical, government, etc. This project was initiated by CenterFocus Internationals, Inc. to redirect focus away from persisting issues with being CDEI Officers to instead, highlight the transformative changes, powerful influence, and sustainable impact these leaders have been able to achieve is a challenging work and political environment. On a team of two, I am using MAXQDA software to code 60 interviews with CDEIOs from across the world to identity significant patterns that can be presented and discussed at the 2023 Martha Vineyard‚Äôs Chief Diversity Office Summit titled ‚ÄúThe Evolving CDO: From Affirmative Action to Belonging.‚Äù This summit will be an opportunity for CDOs to connect, learn best practices in their field, discuss challenges and celebrate the exceptional progress in their line of work.
positions.title: Chief Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Officers Impact Study Coding Consultant
positions.description_html: I currently work as a lead qualitative data coding specialist for an international study seeking to measure the impact of Chief Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Officers across a range of sectors such as technology, law, corporate, medical, government, etc. This project was initiated by CenterFocus Internationals, Inc. to redirect focus away from persisting issues with being CDEI Officers to instead, highlight the transformative changes, powerful influence, and sustainable impact these leaders have been able to achieve is a challenging work and political environment. On a team of two, I am using MAXQDA software to code 60 interviews with CDEIOs from across the world to identity significant patterns that can be presented and discussed at the 2023 Martha Vineyard’s Chief Diversity Office Summit titled “The Evolving CDO: From Affirmative Action to Belonging.” This summit will be an opportunity for CDOs to connect, learn best practices in their field, discuss challenges and celebrate the exceptional progress in their line of work.

positions.subtitle: CenterFocus International, Inc.
positions.description: I worked as the lead qualitative data coding specialist on a project that CenterFocus International, Inc. contracted with DocuSign. On a team of two, I used the software MAXQDA to code 20 executive leader interviews and 25 five employee focus groups from across the world to identity significant patterns and themes that could help DocuSign‚Äôs globalize DEI practices and improve retention amongst its marginal groups. I used the 906 codes created from executive leaders‚Äô responses and 1036 codes assigned to focus group discussions to cowrite an extensive 100 page descriptive and analytical report that was used to inform DocuSign‚Äôs DEI climate assessment and develop new policies and organizational cultural practices that foster inclusion and belonging on a global scale. Two reports derived from the data was used for CenterFocus International, Inc. to present a PowerPoint about tangible DEI recommendations to DocuSign‚Äôs newly hired Chief Diversity Equity and Inclusion Officer.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: I serve as a fellow for the First Year Summer Connect Program ‚Äìa summer course designed to equip incoming freshman and transfer students with a mentor, peer groups, and professional development activities that help them transition to being a Berkeley student. Summer Connect aims to help students chart their own path to exploring and pursuing research opportunities at the number one public university in the world. As a mentor, I facilitate one-on-one and group discussions to mitigate the intimidation of Berkeley‚Äôs competitive academic environment. The goal is to guide students to identify and connect with the people, places, and programs that constitutes a supportive community that motivates them achieve their academic, professional, social and personal goals.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: I served as the program director and instructor for Berkeley Connect- a campus wide course designed to equip students with mentorship, resources, and small-group discussions that foster their belonging at UC, Berkeley. As program director, I developed, directed, coordinated, and implemented a curriculum for 80 students (across a range of disciplines such as STEM, Humanities, Social Sciences, and Business) who registered for Berkeley Connect African American Studies and Ethnic Studies. I structured the curriculum to help students to cultivate a supportive community, expose them to campus resources/centers, and provide them with strategic graduate student mentorship. My role as an instructor entailed facilitating professional development workshops, taking my students on field trips, hosting office hours and facilitating seminars that focused on student challenges and success with navigating Berkeley. Each of these programmatic components boosted the academic, social, professional and personal development of students from all grade levels, racial-ethnic backgrounds, transfers from community college, and other marginal groups.

positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: In response to growing campaigns to combat anti-Black racism in 2020, the Department of Sociology at UC, Berkeley received a grant to fund the Sociology, Equity, Inclusion and Diversity Fellowship. SEID‚Äôs aim is to facilitate necessary dialogues and spaces that center the Sociology‚Äôs department‚Äôs marginalized students, and to appreciate the multiplicity and complexity in which that marginalization occurs. The fellowship contributes to realizing the department's goals of advancing equity, inclusion, and diversity in the areas of department climate, community building, and curriculum. I served as one of the three Community Builder Fellows, who were tasked with coordinating and hosting events that increased opportunities to bond, expanded professional networks, facilitated difficult dialogues, and orchestrated self-care activities amongst graduate students, faculty, and undergraduates.

The Berkeley Social Sciences Division HBCU Fellowship aspires to assist HBCU fellows with gaining critical research skills, initiating strategic professional development, navigating faculty mentorship, and establishing familiarity with Black graduate student life. positions.subtitle: University of California, Berkeley
positions.description: To help resolve racial disparities in the academy The Department of Sociology at UC Berkeley acquired a grant from the University of California Office of the President to establish a rigorous, yet nourishing pipeline program. The Summer Research Scholars of Race recruits and trains students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (Spelman, Howard, and Hampton) and Hispanic-Serving Institutions to work on projects addressing the sociology of race and inequality. Scholars become competitive PhD applicants in the social sciences with guidance from faculty and graduate student mentors.Responsibilities-   Reviewed applications and deliberated program acceptance-  Coordinated the virtual and on-campus program structure- Scheduled and outlined faculty seminars, professional development workshops, prospectus clusters, social activities, and collaborations with similar programs- Facilitated professional development workshops focused on applying to graduate school, graduate student lifestyle , Black graduate student resiliency, conference preparation- Served as a graduate student mentor to students developing senior thesis prospectus on research focusing on race with special emphasis on gender, transnationalism, criminal justice system, colorism, gentrification, community organizing - Planned and executed social activities with fellows and graduate students - Prepared a budget proposal to execute the multiple sectors of the program- Coordinated checkins, follow-ups and connections between cohorts post summer participation
positions.title: Berkeley Sociology Summer Research Scholars of Race Program Associate Director
positions.description_html:
To help resolve racial disparities in the academy The Department of Sociology at UC Berkeley acquired a grant from the University of California Office of the President to establish a rigorous, yet nourishing pipeline program. The Summer Research Scholars of Race recruits and trains students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (Spelman, Howard, and Hampton) and Hispanic-Serving Institutions to work on projects addressing the sociology of race and inequality. Scholars become competitive PhD applicants in the social sciences with guidance from faculty and graduate student mentors.

Responsibilities
- Reviewed applications and deliberated program acceptance
- Coordinated the virtual and on-campus program structure
- Scheduled and outlined faculty seminars, professional development workshops, prospectus clusters, social activities, and collaborations with similar programs
- Facilitated professional development workshops focused on applying to graduate school, graduate student lifestyle , Black graduate student resiliency, conference preparation
- Served as a graduate student mentor to students developing senior thesis prospectus on research focusing on race with special emphasis on gender, transnationalism, criminal justice system, colorism, gentrification, community organizing
- Planned and executed social activities with fellows and graduate students
- Prepared a budget proposal to execute the multiple sectors of the program
- Coordinated checkins, follow-ups and connections between cohorts post summer participation

experience.title: Research Consultant
experience.description: Worked as the primary analyst for strategic fundraising with the TransFormation Alliance, which is a broad partnership of organizations from private, public, and non-profit sectors dedicated to equitable development in Atlanta. I compiled a list of ten alliances similar to TFA and utilized eight categories of organizational components to compare and contrast their funding structures. This comparative analysis along with ethnographic notes on organizational meetings and interviews with alliance members were used to complete a funding development plan that could maximize TFA's financial growth.

experience.title: Research Fellow
experience.description: The National Trust for Historic Preservation African American Cultural Heritage Fund selected ten research fellows to study affordability issues and risk of displacement in Black neighborhoods across major cities in U.S.. These case studies contribute to a national report that maps out the landscape of preservation efforts in Black neighborhoods amid the contemporary resurgence in non-Black migration to metropolitan areas. Assigned to research Atlanta I conducted a neighborhood study utilizing extensive participant observations and in-depth semi-structured interviews to collect and analyze data on revitalization efforts. I also developed a socio-spacial analysis of neighborhood transformation through identifying visual cultural markers in infrastructure, historical landmarks and demographic shifts. The process of finalizing the case narrative entailed conference calls, submitting memos, implementing constructive feedback and collaborations with peers on research developments. We presented our findings at the National PastForward Conference.

experience.title: Brighter Future Fellow: Math Paraprofessional
experience.description: Thomasville Heights was the lowest performing school in the state of Georgia. Instead of allowing them to close, Purpose Built School decided to remodel the building, invest in after school programs, offer recess, provide additional subject area labs, and assign paraprofessionals with the main teachers. This position necessitated that I assist the math teacher in developing lesson plans/unit plans/rubrics/assessments, executing curriculum, and supporting students to achieve academic performances on their grade level. I also compiled data on students to inform instructional decisions, provided individual guidances to students, scheduled reasonable deadlines, and collaborated with other instructors. Teaching the class required excellent written and oral communication skills.

name: Cassius McNeill
position: Freshman | Intended Business Administration Major @ UC Berkeley
about:
Cassius McNeill is a freshman at the University of California, Berkeley, intending to major in Business Administration. Motivated by a deep love for problem-solving, Cassius is drawn to the field of consulting, where he hopes to collaborate with mission-driven organizations to tackle complex challenges and create sustainable, community-centered solutions. He‚Äôs passionate about learning from forward-thinking leaders and contributing to projects that spark long-term impact.

Growing up throughout Southern California, Cassius developed the ability to adapt quickly and connect with people from all walks of life. This flexibility and adaptability continue to fuel his approach to leadership and teamwork.

Cassius‚Äô commitment to uplifting others began in high school, where he served as co-president of the Fellowship for Christian Athletes (FCA) during his junior and senior years. Alongside his fellow leaders, he worked to encourage students to pursue their faith while advocating for mental health awareness, suicide prevention, and opposition to gang affiliation. Through consistent outreach, free meals at every meeting, and hosting guest speakers, Cassius helped cultivate a space where thousands of students felt seen, heard, and empowered.

He also spent several years volunteering at the House of Discipline, a martial arts school and summer program in his hometown of Spring Valley, California. There, he mentored, taught, and supported children, gaining key skills in communication, multitasking, and patience.

These formative experiences solidified Cassius‚Äôs belief in business as a tool for transformation‚Äîone that can build bridges across communities, spark innovation, and amplify the voices of youth and people of color. As he continues his undergraduate journey, Cassius is eager to explore hands-on consulting experiences that allow him to serve others by doing what he loves most: solving problems that matter.

experience.title: AI Startup Marketing and Financial Strategy Analyst
experience.description: FUSE AI is a revolutionary AI ecosystem that allows for seamless AI interactions across all platforms, removing user-facing AI accessibility barriers. Developers have the opportunity to engage in cross-compatibility and utilize built-in overarching capabilities, creating a one-stop shop for AI tools. My role consists of crafting and executing comprehensive pre-seed marketing strategies aligned with startup goals and target audience needs. I also have to conduct thorough market research to identify opportunities, monitor competitors, and continuously refine our strategy. Finally, I manage the marketing budget, ensuring optimal allocation of resources for maximum impact in the pre-seed stage. I also have the opportunity to utilize data-driven approaches to evaluate the effectiveness of campaigns, refining strategies based on ROI metrics.

experience.title: Director of Client Services
experience.description: In this role, I managed three teams of Workforce Specialists (a total of 18 team members) who empowered job seekers to find meaningful employment through innovative programming, impactful job search counseling, and robust connections to social services. Utilizing Human Centered Design principles, we re-imagined the ways in which job seekers search for and secure positions within the Bay Area. Additionally, I created an internal culture of competency-based learning through comprehensive program needs assessments, targeted professional development trainings, and iterative feedback sessions with team members.

Additionally, I created an internal culture of competency-based learning through comprehensive program needs assessments, targeted professional development trainings, and iterative feedback sessions with team members.

experience.title: Program Liaison, FEMA Corps Branch
experience.description: In this role, I liaised with the AmeriCorps National Community Civilian Corps (NCCC) to implement the FEMA Corps Program on a national level. I developed an interactive, evidence-based preparedness education program for young adults and high school youth, and trained over 800 FEMA Corps Members to teach the program in schools across the country. I created and maintained the FEMA Corps Alumni group, building a career pipeline for FEMA Corps Alumni to find meaningful employment in the field of emergency management and community preparedness.

experience.title: Presidential Management Fellow
experience.description: In Spring 2009, I was selected as a Presidential Management Fellow (PMF), the flagship leadership development program in the Federal Government for students with advanced degrees. In 2009, the PMF program had a 15% acceptance rate, with over 5,000 applicants. As a PMF, I rotated through numerous offices within the National Cancer Institute, including the Office of Advocacy Relations, the Office of Cancer Survivorship and the Office of Government and Congressional Relations, leading and collaborating on projects that strengthened strategic partnerships with external stakeholders. Additionally, I detailed with the Health and Human Services Center for Faith-based and Neighborhood Partnerships, collaborating on various public health resources and toolkits for faith and community based organizations during the H1N1 Flu Season.
experience.description_html:
In Spring 2009, I was selected as a Presidential Management Fellow (PMF), the flagship leadership development program in the Federal Government for students with advanced degrees. In 2009, the PMF program had a 15% acceptance rate, with over 5,000 applicants.

As a PMF, I rotated through numerous offices within the National Cancer Institute, including the Office of Advocacy Relations, the Office of Cancer Survivorship and the Office of Government and Congressional Relations, leading and collaborating on projects that strengthened strategic partnerships with external stakeholders. Additionally, I detailed with the Health and Human Services Center for Faith-based and Neighborhood Partnerships, collaborating on various public health resources and toolkits for faith and community based organizations during the H1N1 Flu Season.
